questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not need dose adjustment in renal failure? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Linagliptin

 

Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes. Unlike other DPP-4 inhibitors, linagliptin is primarily excreted via the enterohepatic system, with only a small fraction eliminated by the kidneys. Therefore, it does not require dose adjustments in patients with renal impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sitagliptin: This DPP-4 inhibitor is primarily excreted by the kidneys, and its dose usually needs to be adjusted in patients with renal impairment.

 

Option B. Saxagliptin: Saxagliptin and its active metabolite are primarily eliminated by the kidneys, necessitating dose adjustments in patients with renal failure.

 

Option C. Vildagliptin: Vildagliptin is partially excreted by the kidneys, and dose adjustment is recommended in patients with moderate to severe renal impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Linagliptin is a unique DPP-4 inhibitor that does not require dose adjustments in patients with renal failure due to its primary excretion via the enterohepatic system. This makes it an advantageous option for managing type 2 diabetes in patients with compromised renal function.

questions.text: A patient has the freedom to pick his or her caretaker and future course of action in treatment under the Mental Health Care Act of 2017. What is the name of this provision? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Advance directive

 

Under the Mental Health Care Act of 2017 in India, the provision allowing a patient to choose his or her caretaker and future course of action in treatment is termed the “Advance directive”. It is a legal document wherein the individual specifies the type of treatment they want or don't want, should they become mentally ill and be unable to make competent decisions in the future.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment directive, Option B. Mental will, and Option C. Future directive are not the correct terms used in the context of the Mental Health Care Act of 2017.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Under the Mental Health Care Act 2017 in India, individuals can use an "Advance Directive" to state the way they wish to be treated for a mental illness and the way they wish not to be treated for a mental illness. This provision empowers individuals to have a say in their treatment even if they become incapacitated in the future. This is applicable only if a person loses the capacity to make mental healthcare or treatment decisions. Individuals can also appoint “Nominated Representative (NR)”, who will help in taking decisions regarding the treatment if he or she loses the capacity to make decision.

 

Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian Laws and Mental Health, Page No 42.

questions.text: A biostatistics professor is teaching a group of medical students about the fundamentals of statistics. She mentions a branch that is specifically concerned with summarizing and presenting data in a meaningful way. Which of the following branches is she most likely referring to? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Descriptive statistics

 

Descriptive Statistics:

 

  • Data is summarised through the given observations; summarisation is done from a sample of population using parameters such as the mean or standard deviation.
  • Descriptive statistics is a way to organise, represent and describe a collection of data using tables, graphs, and summary measures

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Theoretical statistics: Focuses on the underlying mathematical theory and development of statistical methods, not on data summarization and presentation.

 

Option C. Analytical statistics: This term is less commonly used and does not represent a standard branch of statistics like descriptive or inferential statistics.

 

Option D. Inferential Statistics: Involves using data from a sample to make predictions or inferences about a larger population, including hypothesis testing and confidence intervals.

 

Additional Information

 

Applied Statistics:

 

  • Pure statistics focuses primarily on the numbers, maths, and problems themselves (theoretical)
  • Applied statistics on the other hand, can be thought of as “statistics-in-action” or using statistics with an eye toward real-world problems and what their solutions might be.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Descriptive statistics is dedicated to summarizing and presenting data in an easily understandable way, utilizing tables, graphs, and summary measures.

choices.text: Lifestyle modification and weight loss
Ursodeoxycholic acid and lifestyle modification
Lifestyle modifications and vitamin E
Pioglitazone and lifestyle modifications

questions.text: A patient with a history of consumption of 2-3 drinks per week comes with complaints of right upper quadrant discomfort. He has grade 2 steatosis. His BMI was 29 kg/m² and AST and ALT levels were slightly elevated. What would you advise him? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lifestyle modification and weight loss

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient is likely suffering from non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), specifically non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), given his history of minimal alcohol consumption, grade 2 steatosis, elevated BMI, and mildly elevated liver enzymes (AST and ALT). The cornerstone of treatment for NASH is lifestyle modification and weight loss. These interventions help reduce liver fat, inflammation, and fibrosis. No FDA-approved medications currently exist for the treatment of NASH; thus, lifestyle changes are the primary recommended approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ursodeoxycholic acid and lifestyle modification: Ursodeoxycholic acid is used for primary biliary cholangitis, not NASH, and thus is not appropriate here.

 

Option C. Lifestyle modifications and vitamin E: Vitamin E can be used off-label in non-diabetic patients with NASH but is not FDA-approved or considered first-line treatment. It can be considered but is secondary to lifestyle changes.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone and lifestyle modifications: Pioglitazone, along with other medications like metformin and GLP-1 receptor agonists, is sometimes used off-label for diabetic patients with NASH. However, it is not FDA-approved for NASH and should not be the first-line recommendation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lifestyle modification and weight loss are the primary and most effective treatments for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), as no FDA-approved medications are currently available for this condition.

questions.text: Choose the correctly matched pairs regarding the drugs used in schizophrenia:(INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1,2,4

 

Schizophrenia is managed with antipsychotic drugs that act on various neurotransmitter systems. Understanding their mechanisms of action and effects is essential for appropriate treatment. Here's a detailed look at each pair:

 

1. D2 antagonism – Reduces positive symptoms:

  •  
  • True. Positive symptoms of schizophrenia, such as hallucinations and delusions, are primarily managed by blocking dopamine D2 receptors. Typical antipsychotics like haloperidol and chlorpromazine are potent D2 antagonists and effectively reduce these symptoms.

 

2. 5HT2A antagonism – Reduces negative symptoms:

  •  
  • True. Atypical antipsychotics (e.g., clozapine, olanzapine) act by blocking serotonin 5HT2A receptors. This action helps to improve both the positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia, with a significant impact on negative symptoms like social withdrawal and apathy.

 

4. Muscarinic receptor antagonism – Reduces extrapyramidal symptoms:

  •  
  • True. Antagonism of muscarinic receptors can help reduce extrapyramidal side effects (EPS) caused by D2 antagonism. Drugs like benztropine, which are anticholinergics, are used to manage EPS by balancing the cholinergic and dopaminergic activities in the brain.

 

Other Options

 

3. 5HT1A agonism – Weight loss:

 

    • False. The 5HT1A receptor agonism is not directly associated with weight loss. In fact, weight gain is a common side effect of many atypical antipsychotics, which act on multiple serotonin and dopamine receptors. The statement should be regarding 5HT2C antagonism, which is associated with weight gain, not loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antipsychotic drugs manage schizophrenia by targeting various neurotransmitter systems. D2 antagonism helps reduce positive symptoms, while 5HT2A antagonism improves negative symptoms. Muscarinic receptor antagonism can help mitigate extrapyramidal side effects. Misconceptions about receptor effects, such as 5HT1A agonism causing weight loss, need to be corrected.

questions.text: A young female presents with pain in lower abdomen and vomiting in the ER. Clinical examination reveals a swelling, lateral and below the public tubercle. X-ray show intestinal obstruction. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strangulated femoral hernia

 

This type of hernia occurs just below the inguinal ligament, where the abdominal contents protrude through the femoral canal. It is more common in women, especially those with repeated pregnancies. The description of the swelling's location lateral and below the pubic tubercle fits well with a femoral hernia. If the hernia becomes strangulated, it means that the blood supply to the herniated tissue is compromised, leading to severe pain, vomiting, and signs of intestinal obstruction as seen on X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adhesions: Bands of fibrous tissue that can form between abdominal tissues and organs, often as a result of surgery can lead to intestinal obstruction if they cause the intestines to twist or kink. However, adhesions themselves do not cause noticeable swelling as described in the scenario.

 

Option B. Strangulated inguinal hernia: This will present with a swelling above the pubic tubercle.

 

Option D. Appendicular mass: This refers to a mass formed from a swollen, inflamed appendix often associated with appendicitis. While this can lead to pain and vomiting, the location of the pain and swelling typically would be around the lower right quadrant of the abdomen, not below the pubic tubercle.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Given the location of the swelling and the associated symptoms, the most probable diagnosis is a Strangulated Femoral Hernia. This condition requires prompt surgical intervention to relieve the obstruction and restore blood flow to the entrapped tissues to prevent further complications such as tissue necrosis.

questions.text: High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA) is not caused by: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diarrhea

 

Diarrhea causes Normal Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA), not High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA). There are only three main causes of NAGMA, remembered by the mnemonic "DRS":

 

  • D: Diarrhea
  • R: RTA (Renal Tubular Acidosis – types 1, 2, and 4)
  • S: Saline administration (causing hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA): Incorrect. DKA is a classic cause of HAGMA. It leads to accumulation of ketone bodies, causing high anion gap.

 

Option C. Acute renal failure: Incorrect. Renal failure causes HAGMA due to accumulation of organic acids and decreased acid excretion.

 

Option D. Inborn errors of metabolism: Incorrect. Most inborn errors of metabolism cause HAGMA through accumulation of organic acids.

 

The causes of HAGMA can be remembered using the mnemonic "GOLDMARK":

 

  • G: Glycol (ethylene glycol)
  • O: Oxoproline (paracetamol metabolite)
  • L: L-lactate
  • D: D-lactate (short bowel syndrome)
  • M: Methanol
  • A: Aspirin
  • R: Renal failure
  • K: Ketoacidosis (diabetic, alcoholic, starvation)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diarrhea causes Normal Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA), not High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA).

questions.text: Following a hysterectomy, the patient received morphine for pain management both during the post-operative period and while in the ward. The current symptoms include respiratory depression and constricted (pinpoint) pupils. What would be the recommended medication for this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Naloxone

 

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of opioid poisoning due to morphine, for which IV Naloxone can be administered.
  • In Morphine poisoning, the patient usually present in comatose state with low BP and heart rate as μ-receptor causes depression of brain including cardiovascular center.

 

SYMPTOMS OF OPIOID POISONING

 

  • Coma, respiratory depression, pinpoint pupils
  • Hypotension, bradycardia
  • Bradypnea
  • Hypothermia

 

ANTAGONISTS

 

  • Naloxone - Short acting, given iv
  • Naltrexone - Long acting, given Orally
  • DOC for acute opioid poisoning → Naloxone
  • DOC for maintenance in opioid poisoning → Naltrexone
    • Naloxone is added to oral opioids to reduce addictive potential.
    • Naltrexone is used to decrease craving in alcoholics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pethidine/Meperidine is a μ receptor agonist.

 

Option B. Atropine is an anticholinergic drug. Used in cases of organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option D. Buprenorphine is a partial μ receptor agonist and an antagonist at delta and kappa receptor. It has ceiling Effect on respiratory depression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Naloxone is the drug of choice for treating acute opioid overdose, characterized by symptoms such as respiratory depression, pinpoint pupils, and coma. It acts rapidly to reverse the effects of opioids by competitively inhibiting their action at opioid receptors.

choices.text: a, b, c, d are correct

questions.text:
Evaluate the following statements with respect to CTEV.(AIIMS NOV 2019)

 

  1. 50% cases are in males and are bilateral
  2. Forefoot is adducted and supinated
  3. With Ponsetti technique, correction is up to 90%
  4. Equinus should be corrected first
questions.solution:
Ans. A. a, b, c are correct

 

  • CTEV is a congenital foot deformity characterized by several components:

    • Cavus: High arch

    • Adduction: Forefoot turned inward

    • Supination: Sole of the foot turned inward

    • Equinus: Plantarflexion 

    • Varus: Inversion of the heel

 

a. 50% cases are in males and are bilateral: 

 

  • Clubfoot is more common in males than females. The ratio is roughly 2:1. So, more than 50% of cases are in males.

  • Approximately 50% of all clubfoot cases occur in both feet (bilateral).

 

b. Forefoot is adducted and supinated:

 

  • This statement is correct. 

  • As mentioned earlier, forefoot adduction and supination are key components of the clubfoot deformity.

 

c. With Ponsetti technique, correction is up to 90%:

 

  • This statement is considered correct. 

  • The Ponseti method, a non-surgical treatment involving serial casting, has very high success rates, often reported around 90% or even higher when followed properly.

 

Other Option:

 

d. Equinus should be corrected first:

 

  • This statement is incorrect. 

  • The Ponseti method typically follows a specific sequence of correction:

    1. Cavus: Addressing the high arch first.

    2. Adduction and Supination: Correcting the inward turning of the forefoot.

    3. Varus: Correcting the inversion of the heel.

    4. Equinus: Addressing the plantarflexion of the foot, often as the final step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In CTEV, male children are more affected than females. 

  • 50% of cases of CTEV have bilateral lower limb involvement. 

  • There is forefoot adduction and supination in cases of CTEV. 

  • Ponseti method of conservative treatment gives correction of up to 90%. 

 

Equinus deformity is corrected at last, following the C-A-V-E sequence.

questions.text: What is the most common tumor of the lacrimal gland? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pleomorphic adenoma

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the lacrimal gland. This tumor is composed of a mix of ductal and myoepithelial cells, often presenting as a painless, progressive, firm mass typically located in the superolateral aspect of the orbit.

 

Details about Pleomorphic Adenoma:

 

  • Benign Nature: Despite its benign nature, pleomorphic adenoma can cause displacement of the eye and may alter vision due to its size and location.
  • Potential for Malignant Transformation: While it is primarily benign, there is a risk for malignant transformation into a carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma if not adequately treated or if left untreated for a long duration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoid cystic carcinoma: Although this is the most common malignant tumor of the lacrimal gland, it is not as frequently occurring as pleomorphic adenoma. Adenoid cystic carcinoma is known for its aggressive nature and poorer prognosis.

 

Option B. Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma: This type of tumor can involve the lacrimal gland but is generally less common than pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Option D. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma: This is another type of malignant tumor that can occur in the lacrimal gland, but it is also less common than pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the lacrimal gland while adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common malignant tumour of the lacrimal gland. Overall, benign tumours are more common, thus pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumour.

questions.text: Acute inflammatory response is not seen in: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Apoptosis

 

An inflammatory response is not seen in apoptosis. In this process, the cell membrane remains intact. Hence, there is no leakage of cell contents and no surrounding inflammation.

 

On the other hand, other forms of cell death including necrosis, necroptosis, and pyroptosis involve the disintegration of the cell membrane. This causes the cell contents to leak out of the cell leading to an acute inflammatory response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyroptosis: Pyroptosis is a form of cell death associated with inflammation. It involves the activation of caspase-1, leading to the formation of pores in the cell membrane and the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines, ultimately resulting in cell lysis and an inflammatory response.

 

Option B. Necroptosis: Necroptosis is a form of programmed cell death that is morphologically similar to necrosis. It results in cell swelling, membrane rupture, and the release of inflammatory mediators.

 

Option D. Necrosis: Necrosis is an uncontrolled form of cell death that leads to the release of cell contents into the extracellular space, which triggers an inflammatory response.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apoptosis is a non-inflammatory form of programmed cell death, characterized by the maintenance of membrane integrity and the absence of an acute inflammatory response. In contrast, necrosis, necroptosis, and pyroptosis involve membrane rupture and the release of intracellular contents, leading to inflammation.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 33-34

questions.text: DNA Methylation is not involved in?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Base pair excision

 

Base pair excision repair (BER) is a mechanism that corrects DNA damage involving small, non-helix-distorting base lesions. This process is initiated by DNA glycosylases that recognize and remove damaged bases, followed by endonuclease activity, DNA synthesis, and ligation. DNA methylation does not play a direct role in this repair pathway.

 

DNA methylation is usually associated with triggering histone deacetylation, chromatin condensation, and gene silencing. Differentially methylated cytosines give rise to distinct patterns specific for each tissue type and disease state. Such methylation-variable positions (MVPs) are not uniformly distributed throughout our genome, but are concentrated among genes that regulate transcription, growth, metabolism, differentiation, and oncogenesis. Alterations in MVP methylation status create epigenetic patterns that appear to regulate gene expression profiles during cell differentiation, growth, and development, as well as in cancer.

 

Environmental stressors including toxins, as well as microbial and viral exposures, can change epigenetic patterns and thereby effect changes in gene activation and cell phenotype.

It is involved in mismatch repair but not in the base pair excision repair mechanism.

 

Other Options:

 

Roles of DNA Methylation:

 

Option A. Chromatin Remodeling: DNA methylation is involved in chromatin remodeling by recruiting proteins such as methyl-CpG-binding domain proteins (MBDs) that interact with histone deacetylases (HDACs), leading to chromatin condensation and gene silencing.

 

Option B. Mismatch Repair: DNA methylation marks newly synthesized DNA strands during replication, aiding in the identification and repair of mismatches.

 

Option C. Gene Silencing: DNA methylation typically leads to gene silencing by preventing the binding of transcription factors and promoting the formation of a condensed chromatin structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA methylation is not involved in the base pair excision repair mechanism. Instead, it plays significant roles in chromatin remodeling, mismatch repair, and gene silencing by modifying the DNA structure and influencing protein interactions and gene expression.

questions.text: Disruption of the axon with an intact endoneurium is seen in which of the following? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Axonotmesis

 

Disruption of the axon with an intact endoneurium is seen in axonotmesis. In this condition, there is axonal disruption (the inner axon is damaged), which leads to loss of conductivity, but the outer sheath of the nerve, including the endoneurium and perineurium, remains intact.

 

In axonotmesis:

 

  • There is a loss of conduction, but the nerve’s continuity is maintained because the neural tubes are intact. The axon is disrupted, meaning that its continuity is broken, but the endoneurium and perineurium remain intact.
  • It occurs following trauma, such as closed fractures and dislocations.
  • Wallerian degeneration occurs distal to the lesion, where the axon disintegrates and is resorbed by phagocytes. Axonal regeneration then begins, with fine unmyelinated fibers growing from the proximal stumps into the endoneurial tubes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurapraxia: Neurapraxia is a reversible physiological nerve conduction block that causes temporary loss of sensation and motor function. This condition is associated with segmental demyelination without axonal damage. It often follows prolonged compression, such as in Saturday night palsy or crutch palsy.

 

Option B. Axonapraxia: Axonapraxia refers to disruption at the level of the axoplasm and is a temporary failure of nerve conduction. It is not associated with structural damage to the axon itself.

 

Option D. Neurotmesis: Neurotmesis is the complete transection of the nerve trunk, typically associated with more severe injuries like open wounds. In this case, both the axon and the endoneurium are destroyed, leading to significant loss of function. The regenerating axons cannot re-enter the distal segment, resulting in poor recovery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Axonotmesis involves the disruption of the axon while the endoneurium and perineurium remain intact. This allows for axonal regeneration, unlike in more severe injuries like neurotmesis, where complete nerve continuity is lost.

choices.text: Secure airway, ICD placement, and IV fluids
Start IV fluids, give atropine and send for chest x-ray
Administer IV Dextrose and send for CT
Evaluate for head injury and perform surgery

questions.text: A patient with a history of chest trauma with breathlessness on examination is found to have systolic BP of 90 mmHg, SpO2 of 85%, GCS 8/15, absent breath sounds. What is the next step? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Secure airway, ICD placement, and IV fluids

 

Following ATLS principles (A, B, C, D):

 

  • GCS 8/15 ("GCS below 8, intubate") indicates need for immediate airway protection
  • SpO2 85% with absent breath sounds suggests respiratory compromise needing ICD
  • BP 90 mmHg indicates a need for fluid resuscitation. This option follows the correct sequence of resuscitation:
    • Airway (A)
    • Breathing (B) - ICD placement
    • Circulation (C) - IV fluids

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Start IV fluids, give atropine and send for chest x-ray:

 

  • Skips airway management in a patient with GCS 8/15
  • Atropine not indicated in this scenario
  • Imaging should not precede resuscitation

 

Option C. Administer IV Dextrose and send for CT:

 

  • Neglects immediate airway and breathing issues
  • CT scan inappropriate before stabilization
  • IV dextrose not indicated in acute trauma

 

Option D. Evaluate for head injury and perform surgery:

 

  • Ignores immediate airway and breathing concerns
  • Surgery evaluation premature before stabilization
  • Violates ATLS principles of prioritization

 

Educational Objective: 


In trauma, follow ABCDE sequence.

questions.text: Match the following: (INCET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-b, 3-a, 4-c

 

Explanation:

 

1. Football sign: This sign is associated with pneumoperitoneum, where an accumulation of gas in the peritoneal cavity gives a silhouette resembling a football on X-ray images.

 

 

2. Rat tail sign: Typically seen in carcinoma of the esophagus, this sign describes the tapering of the esophageal lumen due to the tumor, resembling a rat’s tail..

 

 

3. String sign: Found in CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis), it refers to the appearance of a narrowed, elongated channel through the pylorus.

 

 

4. Inverted umbrella sign: This is seen in cases of TB (tuberculosis), particularly referring to the appearance of a contracted cecum and narrow ileocecal junction

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry molars
Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson molars
Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry incisors
Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson incisors

questions.text: Which of the following constitutes Hutchinson's triad? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson incisors

 

Hutchinson's triad refers to:

 

  1. Interstitial keratitis
  2. 8th nerve deafness
  3. Hutchinson incisors

 

Commonly seen in late congenital syphilis.

 

 

Features of Hutchinson Teeth:

 

  • Peg-shaped with a crescent-shaped notch
  • Thinning or discoloration of enamel
  • Smaller teeth
  • Widely spaced teeth

 

Mulberry molars:

 

Mulberry molars (also known as Moon or Fournier molars) are also seen in Congenital Syphilis. They are multicuspid first molars in which the tooth's grinding surface, which is narrower than that at the gingival margin, has many small cusps instead of the usual four well-formed cusps.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry molars: Mulberry molars are also seen in congenital syphilis but are not part of Hutchinson's triad. Mulberry molars (also known as Moon or Fournier molars) are first molars with a narrower grinding surface and multiple small cusps rather than the usual four well-formed cusps.

 

Option B. Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson molars: The correct dental component of Hutchinson's triad is Hutchinson incisors, not molars.

 

Option C. Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry incisors: The term "mulberry incisors" is not accurate; Hutchinson incisors are the correct term, which refers to the characteristic dental deformity in Hutchinson's triad.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hutchinson's triad consists of interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, and Hutchinson incisors, and it is a diagnostic feature of late congenital syphilis.

questions.text: A patient came to the emergency department with a history of being involved in a road traffic accident, resulting in a fracture of the femur shaft. The patient's condition was promptly stabilized. However, after a period of 12 hours, the individual experienced a sudden onset of difficulty breathing, confusion, and the appearance of small reddish-purple skin rashes (petechiae) over the chest and underarm areas. What potential diagnosis could explain these symptoms? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fat embolism

 

  • The probable diagnosis derived from the given clinical scenario can be fat embolism.
  • Fat embolism although should be diagnosed with trauma to long bone, usually Femur and clinical presentation of pulmonary involvement, CNS depression and skin involvement (Petechiae).

 

FAT EMBOLISM SYNDROME

 

  • Fat embolism refers to the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of a long bone or other major trauma.
  • Fat embolism syndrome reflects a serious systemic manifestation as a consequence to these emboli.
  • Fat embolism is more commonly seen in patients with multiple fractures and in fractures involving lower limbs especially femur.
  • Fat originates from the site of trauma, particularly from the injured marrow. Fat globules > 10 mm are considered significant.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Early warning signs are a slight rise in temperature and pulse rate (tachycardia).
    • The classical triad of fat embolism syndrome is:
      1. Respiratory symptoms: Dyspnea or tachypnea
      2. Neurological symptoms: Confusion or disorientation
      3. Petechial rash: In axilla, neck, periumbilical area, conjunctiva of lower lid, front and back of chest, shoulder
  • Diagnostic Criterion for Fat Embolism:

 

 

  • 1 major + 4 minor = Fat embolism

 

  • Prevention:
    • Fracture stabilization
    • Removing fat emboli from circulation by:
      • Lipolytic agents as heparin (increase serum lipase activity)
      • Hypertonic glucose (decrease FFA production)
  • Offset its effect by:
    • Dextran (expand plasma volume, reduces RBC aggregation and platelet adherence)
    • Aprotinin (protease inhibitor) – decreases platelet aggregation and serotonin release
    • Alcohol has vasodilator and lipolytic effect.
  • Treatment:
    • The aim of treatment is maintaining adequate oxygen level in the blood. If necessary, by using intermittent positive pressure ventilation. Oxygen is the only therapeutic tool of proven use.
    • It should be administered in sufficient amount to maintain arterial PO2 > 80 mm Hg. O2 toxicity (pneumonitis) is avoided by using O2 conc. below 40%.
    • Steroids are given to Avoid Pneumonitis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Head injury. Based on the mechanism, head trauma is classified as blunt (the most common mechanism), penetrating (most fatal), and blast. Most severe TBIs result from motor vehicle collisions and falls. A good history concerning the mechanism of injury is important. GCS is used to describe the level of consciousness. A patient with mild head injury may present with swelling from a bump or a bruise, small, superficial cut in the scalp, headache, sensitivity to noise and light, irritability, confusion, dizziness, balance problems, nausea, problems with memory and/or concentration, blurred vision, tinnitus. Moderate to severe head injury symptoms may include any of the above plus loss of consciousness, severe headache that does not go away, repeated nausea and vomiting, loss of short-term memory, such as difficulty remembering the events that led right up to and through the traumatic event, slurred speech, difficulty with walking, weakness in one side or area of the body, sweating, pale skin, seizures, blood or clear fluid draining from the ears or nose, one pupil  is dilated, or looks larger, than the other eye and doesn't constrict, or get smaller, when exposed to light , deep cut or laceration in the scalp, open wound in the head, foreign object penetrating the head, coma.

 

Option C. Blunt trauma to chest. Chest trauma remains a serious problem in high-speed vehicle accidents. Thoracic trauma occurs in approximately 60% patients and has a mortality of 20-25%. The mortality rate in blunt chest trauma may be due to pulmonary and non-pulmonary complications. In the primary survey of chest trauma patients, 6 life-threatening conditions (airway obstruction, tension pneumothorax, open pneumothorax, massive hemothorax, flail chest, pericardial tamponade) should be immediately investigated and treated. Signs and symptoms of thoracic trauma include cyanosis of fingers, lips or face, dyspnea, tachypnea or bradypnea, contusion, laceration, perforations, distension, hemoptysis, signs of shock (hypoperfusion), tracheal deviation, paradoxical movement of the chest wall, distended jugular veins, decreased or absent breathing sounds, pain, failure of chest expansion in normal inspiration. Respiratory distress is a serious problem and the patients may breathe with nasal flaring, using accessory muscles, intercostal and subcostal retractions, and tachypnea. The patient's lungs may not be equally involved in breathing. Paradoxical respiration can be observed and immediate diagnosis of flail chest can be made.

 

Option D. Hemorrhagic shock. Shock refers to the inadequate perfusion of tissues due to the imbalance between the oxygen demand of tissues and the body’s ability to supply it. Blunt or penetrating trauma is the most common cause, followed by upper and lower gastrointestinal sources. Bleeding may be either external or internal. It occurs due to the depletion of intravascular volume through blood loss to the point of being unable to match the tissues demand for oxygen. As a result, mitochondria are unable to sustain aerobic metabolism for the production of oxygen and switch to the less efficient anaerobic metabolism to meet the cellular demand for adenosine triphosphate which leads to pyruvate production and conversion to lactic acid to maintain some degree of cellular respiration. The body compensates by increasing heart rate and contractility, followed by baroreceptor activation resulting in sympathetic nervous system activation and peripheral vasoconstriction. Signs and symptoms include blue lips and finger nails, low or no urine output, excessive sweating, shallow breathing, dizziness or loss of consciousness, confusion, chest pain, low blood pressure, rapid heart rate, weak pulse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • History of a road traffic accident, resulting in a fracture of the femur shaft with appearance of symptoms of sudden onset of difficulty breathing, confusion, and small reddish-purple skin rashes over the chest and underarm areas after a period of 12 hours all indicates fat embolism which needs immediate intervention.

questions.text:
In atrial fibrillation, choose the correct statements: (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Novel oral anticoagulants (NOACs) used in the treatment of moderate to severe MS
  2. Anticoagulants should be given in patients with ischemic stroke due to atrial fibrillation
  3. NOACs are contraindicated in prosthetic valves
  4. All patients with atrial fibrillation who are not candidates for cardiac surgery can be started on beta-blockers
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 and 3 correct

 

Anticoagulants are indicated for ischemic stroke due to atrial fibrillation. NOACs are contraindicated in patients with prosthetic valves due to a lack of evidence on their efficacy and safety in this population.

 

Other Options:

 

1. NOACs are not used for moderate to severe mitral stenosis.

 

4. Beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers are used for rate control but not universally applicable.

 

Educational Objective:


Anticoagulants are used for ischemic stroke in AF, and NOACs are contraindicated in prosthetic valves.

choices.text: Commonly presents in the 20-40 years age group
Matrix consists of proliferating mononuclear cells
Osteoclast giant cells constitute the proliferative component of the tumor
It is a benign tumor which may have lung metastasis

questions.text: About giant-cell tumor, all are true except:(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Osteoclast giant cells constitute the proliferative component of the tumor

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue. 
    • The osteoclast giant cells are the malignant cells, which induce the proliferation of mononuclear macrophage-lineage cells, hence the dividing cell population is the mononuclear cells which form the matrix.
    • The proliferative component of a giant cell tumor (GCT) is primarily made up of the mononuclear stromal cells, which are mesenchymal in origin.
    • These stromal cells are the neoplastic (tumor-forming) cells of GCT and play a central role in tumor growth and aggressiveness.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. 
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT. 
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
  • Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of multinucleated giant cells (40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells). 
  • The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of the giant cells, a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumors from other tumors that may contain many giant cells. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Giant cell tumors commonly presents in the 20-40 years of age group. 
  • Microscopically, the matrix consists of proliferating mononuclear cells.
  • Osteoclast giant cells induce the proliferation of the monoculcear macrophage cells, increasing the mononuclear cell population. 
  • It is a benign tumor which may have lung metastasis in about 4% cases.

questions.text: Silent choroid on FFA is a feature of which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stargardt's disease

 

Silent choroid / Dark choroid on FFA is a feature of Stargardt's disease.

 

 

The 'silent choroid' or 'dark choroid' phenomenon is caused by the obscuration of the background choroidal fluorescence due to diffuse abnormalities in the retinal epithelium (RE). The accumulation of lipofuscin within the RE is a hallmark feature of Stargardt disease / Fundus flavimaculatus (FFM), which is the most prevalent type of macular dystrophy.

 

Signs:

 

  • The macula may initially be normal, later progressing to an oval 'snail slime' or 'beaten bronze appearance and subsequently to geographic atrophy.
  • Numerous yellow-white round, oval or fish-shaped lesions are seen at the level of the RPE.

 

Investigations:

 

  • Visual fields show central loss
  • FFA - Dark choroid, the macula shows mixed hyper and hypofluorescence. Indocyanine green angiography (ICGA). shows hypofluorescent spots.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Best's disease: This condition is characterized by the accumulation of lipofuscin-like material within the RPE but does not typically feature a silent choroid on FFA.

 

Option C. Age-related macular degeneration (AMD): AMD is associated with drusen and neovascular changes rather than a silent choroid.

 

Option D. Cystoid macular edema: This involves swelling of the macular region of the retina due to fluid accumulation in the cystoid spaces, not linked with the silent choroid phenomenon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The silent choroid or dark choroid on FFA is a distinctive feature of Stargardt's disease, caused by lipofuscin accumulation in the retinal pigment epithelium, which blocks the normal choroidal fluorescence. Recognizing this feature is crucial in diagnosing and differentiating Stargardt’s disease from other macular disorders.

choices.text: 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix

questions.text: All of the following are the diagnostic criteria for preterm labor except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cervix posterior in position

 

Explanation:

 

Preterm labor (PTL) is labor that occurs before the 37th week of gestation. Accurate diagnosis involves evaluating several key criteria:

 

  • Contractions: At least one regular contraction every 10 minutes, or 4 contractions in 20 minutes, or 8 contractions in 60 minutes, with or without pain.
  • Cervical Changes: Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm and more than 80% effacement are significant indicators of preterm labor.

 

The incorrect statement is Option D. A cervix that is posterior in position is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. Instead, the cervix's position may be less relevant than its dilation and effacement in the diagnosis of preterm labor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix: Correct. Regular contractions that meet the criteria of 4 in 20 minutes or 8 in 60 minutes, along with changes in the cervix, are used to diagnose preterm labor.

 

Option B. Cervical dilatation > 2 cm: Correct. Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm is a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.

 

Option C. More than 80 percent effaced cervix: Correct. Cervical effacement greater than 80% is another diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cervix being in a posterior position is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. The diagnosis involves assessing contraction patterns and cervical changes such as dilation and effacement.

 

Ref: Page no 366, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: A patient is on phenytoin for a seizure disorder. He was prescribed sucralfate 4 times a day for peptic ulcers. What should be the minimum duration of time between consumption of these drugs? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 120 minutes

 

  • Sucralfate is made up of aluminium octosulphate of sucrose. In the acidic pH of the stomach, it gets polymerized into a viscous fluid which adheres to the base of the ulcer for upto 6 hours. However, this viscous layer prevents the absorption of other drugs like phenytoin, ketoconazole, fluoroquinolones etc. from the stomach.
  • When a patient is taking both phenytoin (an antiepileptic drug) and sucralfate (a medication used to treat peptic ulcers), it's important to manage the timing of these medications to avoid drug interactions.
  • Sucralfate can interfere with the absorption of phenytoin when taken too closely together, leading to reduced effectiveness of phenytoin.
  • The general recommendation is to separate the administration of these two drugs by at least 2 hours. This separation allows sufficient time for the phenytoin to be absorbed before the sucralfate is taken, which can bind to drugs in the gastrointestinal tract and hinder their absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The minimum duration of time between the consumption of phenytoin and sucralfate should be at least 120 minutes (2 hours) to ensure that phenytoin is adequately absorbed and to avoid interactions that could reduce its effectiveness.

questions.text: The most common bleeding manifestation seen in severe hemophilia is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recurrent hemarthrosis


Recurrent hemarthrosis, or bleeding into joints, is the most common bleeding manifestation in patients with severe hemophilia. Hemophilia is classified as severe when the residual activity of factor VIII or factor IX is less than 1%. Hemophilia is an X-linked recessive bleeding disorder caused by mutations in either the F8 gene (hemophilia A) or the F9 gene (hemophilia B). Both types present with similar clinical symptoms, making them indistinguishable without specific laboratory tests. Hemophilia can be further categorized based on residual factor levels as severe (<1%), moderate (1-5%), or mild (6-30%).

 

Patients with severe hemophilia often present with symptoms early in life, such as bleeding after circumcision or upon starting to walk or crawl. The hallmark clinical manifestation is joint bleeding, most commonly affecting the knees. Chronic joint bleeds lead to complications such as synovial thickening, synovitis, and muscle contractures from fixed positioning.

 

Clinical features of hemarthrosis:

 

  • Acute hemarthrosis: Presents with local pain, swelling, erythema, and muscle contractures.
  • Chronic hemarthrosis: Leads to synovial thickening and chronic synovitis due to repeated intra-articular bleeding.
    The most affected joint is termed the "target joint," as it undergoes repeated bleeding episodes.

 

Other bleeding features in hemophilia:

 

  • Muscle hematomas: These can lead to compartment syndromes.
  • Hematuria: Common but self-limiting.
  • Life-threatening bleeds: These include bleeding into oropharyngeal spaces, central nervous system (CNS), and retroperitoneum.

 

Treatment:


Treatment for severe hemophilia involves factor replacement therapy, which significantly improves life expectancy. For hemophilia A, factor VIII is administered, while hemophilia B is treated with factor IX. Factor VIII has a shorter half-life (8-12 hours), necessitating twice-daily injections. In contrast, factor IX has a longer half-life (around 24 hours), allowing for once-daily injections.

 

  • FVIII dosing: Calculated based on target FVIII levels, baseline levels, body weight, and a multiplier of 0.5 unit/kg.
  • FIX dosing: Calculated similarly, with a multiplier of 1 unit/kg.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrent hematomas: While muscle hematomas are common in hemophilia, they are not the most frequent bleeding manifestation compared to hemarthrosis.

 

Option C. Hematuria:  Hematuria can occur in hemophilia but is typically self-limiting and less common than hemarthrosis.

 

Option D. Intracranial hemorrhage: Intracranial hemorrhage is a serious, life-threatening complication in hemophilia but is not the most common presentation. It requires immediate treatment.

 

Educational Objective:


Recurrent hemarthrosis is the most common bleeding manifestation in severe hemophilia, particularly affecting large joints such as the knees.

questions.text: The viruses of the filoviridae family like Ebola and Marburg resemble which of the following morphologies? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3

 

  • Viruses belonging to the filoviridae family, such as Ebola and Marburg, resemble the morphology shown in image 3.
  • Image 3 - Ebola viruses are filamentous viruses with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA as genetic material.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Image 1- Influenza viruses have linear segmented, single-stranded RNA.

 

 

Image 2- Adenovirus is an icosahedroal symmetry with fibres extruding from vertices and contains double-stranded DNA.

 

 

Image 4 - Corona virus is non-segmented single-stranded RNA virus.

 

Coronavirus Structure

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Filoviruses, such as Ebola and Marburg, are filamentous and contain nonsegmented single-stranded RNA.

questions.text: The structure marked with the black arrow in the given picture arises from the ……… (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hippocampus

 

Explanation:

 

This is a coronal section of the brain and the marked structure is the fornix. It arises from the hippocampus and ends in the mammillary body of the hypothalamus.

 

Hippocampus is located in the medial temporal lobe of the brain.

 

The hippocampus is critical for the formation and retrieval of memories, particularly episodic memories. It's also involved in spatial navigation. Damage or atrophy of the hippocampus can result in difficulties forming new memories. Conditions like Alzheimer's disease often exhibit significant hippocampal atrophy.


Other Options:

 

Option A. Mamillary body: Part of the diencephalon, present at the base of the brain, posterior to the pituitary gland.

 

  • The mammillary bodies are primarily associated with memory processing. They receive projections from the hippocampus via the fornix and send projections to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. They're particularly involved in the recall of past memories and are thought to play a role in spatial memory. Damage to the mammillary bodies, often due to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency as seen in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, can lead to memory deficits.

 

Option C. Thalamus: Positioned centrally in the brain, the thalamus is a large mass of gray matter deep within the brain. It is part of the diencephalon.

 

  • Often referred to as the "relay station" of the brain, the thalamus receives sensory and motor signals and relays them to the cerebral cortex. It's involved in consciousness, sleep, and alertness. Thalamic strokes or lesions can lead to sensory deficits, altered consciousness, and movement disorders.

 

Option D. Amygdala: Located in the anterior portion of the temporal lobe, deep within the brain.

 

  • The amygdala plays a pivotal role in processing emotions, particularly fear and pleasure. It helps determine which memories are stored and where they are stored based on emotional significance. Dysfunction of the amygdala can lead to various emotional and behavioral abnormalities. It's also implicated in conditions such as anxiety disorders and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coronal Section of Brain

questions.text:
Mention the true statement/s about digoxin toxicity:(AIIMS MAY 2019)

 

  1. Earliest manifestation of digoxin toxicity is gastrointestinal symptoms
  2. Nonspecific vision changes may be noted in digoxin toxicity
  3. Early toxicity may not correlate with serum levels
  4. Neurological symptoms may occur without corresponding cardiovascular changes
  5. Hypokalemia is associated with increased risk of toxicity
questions.solution:
Ans. A. All are true

 

  • Most common and earliest adverse effect of digoxin is nausea and vomiting (option a).
  • Most common arrhythmia seen in digoxin overdose is ventricular bigeminy.
  • Other adverse effects of digoxin include Gynecomastia and Vision defects (initially non-specific and later yellow vision): Option b
  • Early toxicity may not correlate with serum levels because Digoxin has very high volume of distribution (~450L); So when digoxin reaches heart the plasma concentration may not be high.: Option c
  • Hypokalemia increases the risk of toxicity as the binding site of digoxin and K+ are same on the Na+ K+ pump. So, normally K inhibits the binding of digoxin to Na K pump. When K is less (hypokalemia), binding of digoxin increases and toxicity can result.
  • However, Note that Digoxin toxicity causes hyperkalemia (due to inhibition of Na K pump, K+ cannot enter inside cells and remain in blood, hence hyperkalemia occurs).

 

Educational Objective:

 

All statements about digoxin toxicity, including the earliest manifestations, vision changes, correlation with serum levels, neurological symptoms, and the association with hypokalemia, are true.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/560

questions.text: While performing triage of children who are victims of a school bus accident, which one will you attend to first? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Airway Obstruction

 

The most appropriate answer is airway obstruction.

 

Maintaining a patent airway is crucial for the survival of any trauma patient, especially children. An airway obstruction can quickly lead to severe respiratory distress and, if left untreated, can result in death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Grade 4 Shock: While shock is a critical condition, attending to airway obstruction takes precedence because it directly impacts oxygenation, which is vital for life. Treating shock without addressing airway obstruction may not be effective.

 

Option C. Flail Chest: Flail chest is a serious chest injury, but it may not be an immediate threat to the airway. It should be assessed and treated promptly but is not the first priority compared to airway obstruction.

 

Option D. Severe head injury: Head injuries are also critical, but immediate attention to airway obstruction is necessary to ensure the child's ability to breathe and maintain oxygenation. Head injuries can be assessed and managed after ensuring a clear airway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triage decisions are to be made by deciding which injuries constitute the greatest immediate threat to life.

 

In general, airway problems are more rapidly lethal than breathing problems › circulation problems > neurologic injuries.

questions.text:
Match the following cell types with their associated malignancy. 

 

  1. Popcorn cell
  2. Faggot cell
  3. Cerebriform nuclei
  4. Starry sky

 

  1. Acute promyelocytic leukemia
  2. Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma
  3. Burkitt lymphoma
  4. Sezary syndrome
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

The correct matches are as follows:

 

  • 1. Popcorn cell: b. Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma
    • Popcorn cells, also known as L&H cells, are seen in nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma (NLPHL). These cells are large, with lobulated nuclei that resemble popcorn.
  • 2. Faggot cell: a. Acute promyelocytic leukemia
    • Faggot cells are characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). These cells contain multiple Auer rods in their cytoplasm, giving a bundle-like appearance (faggots).
  • 3. Cerebriform nuclei: d. Sezary syndrome
    • Cerebriform nuclei are seen in Sezary syndrome, a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. The nuclei have a characteristic folded appearance resembling the cerebral cortex.
  • 4. Starry sky: c. Burkitt lymphoma
    • The "starry sky" pattern is observed in Burkitt lymphoma. It refers to the appearance of macrophages (stars) scattered among a background of malignant lymphocytes (sky), due to rapid tumor turnover and apoptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 1-a, 2-d, 3-c, 4-b: Incorrect. Popcorn cells are not seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia; they are associated with lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma. Similarly, faggot cells are seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia, not Sezary syndrome. Cerebriform nuclei are characteristic of Sezary syndrome, not Burkitt lymphoma.

 

Option C. 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c: Incorrect. While the match for the popcorn cell is correct, faggot cells are seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia, not Sezary syndrome. Cerebriform nuclei are associated with Sezary syndrome, not acute promyelocytic leukemia.

 

Option D. 1-a, 2-b, 3-d, 4-c: Incorrect. The popcorn cell is not associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia but with lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma. Similarly, faggot cells are seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia, not lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The student must memorize the key associations of specific cell types with their respective malignancies:

 

  • Popcorn cell: Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • Faggot cell: Acute promyelocytic leukemia
  • Cerebriform nuclei: Sezary syndrome
  • Starry sky: Burkitt lymphoma

questions.text: A 60-year gentleman was referred from outside hospital to AIIMS ER after he developed sudden onset quadriparesis. In hospital patient was treated with 3%NaCl, Oral tolvaptan. Initial metabolic panel revealed Na: 115 mEq/L, K: 2.8 mEq/L, Cl: 85 mEq/L with normal TSH, CBC, RFT, LFT.  What is the most likely cause for this patient's condition?  (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Osmotic demyelination syndrome

 

Previously called central pontine myelinolysis. It occurs due to rapid correction of Chronic Hyponatremia (>8 mg/dL).

 

Timing: 2-6 days after rapid correction.

 

Rx: Irreversible. Desmopressin clamp if overcorrection in q6h Na values.  

 

Mechanism:

 

1. In Hyponatremia

 

 

2. On sudden correction:

 

 

Risk factors:

 

  1. Serum sodium ≤ 105 mEq/L
  2. Concurrent hypokalemia
  3. Chronic excess alcohol intake
  4. Acute or chronic hepatic disease
  5. Malnourishment

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brain infarct: Not directly suggested by the rapid onset of symptoms following electrolyte correction.

 

Option B. Brainstem injury: Could be considered but is less likely without trauma or vascular insult history.

 

Option D. Rare cause of hypernatremia: Not applicable as the condition involves the rapid correction of hyponatremia, not hypernatremia itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia should be avoided to prevent the severe neurological complications associated with osmotic demyelination syndrome. Control and monitoring of serum sodium levels are crucial during treatment.

 

Reference - Harrison/Electrolytes/Chap 53

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding the tape shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

 

  1. It is called Shelter's tape.
  2. It is used to assess severe acute malnutrition.
  3. Reading of 13.5 to 14.5 cm is considered undernourished.
  4. It is useful mainly for frontline field workers.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4

 

The tape shown in the image is known as Shakir's tape (not Shelter's tape). It is a tool primarily used to assess Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) in children aged 6-59 months by measuring the Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC).

 

Key Points:

 

  • Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM): Shakir's tape is specifically designed to measure the MUAC, which is an important indicator of malnutrition. MUAC is a quick and reliable method for assessing malnutrition, especially in resource-limited settings.
  • MUAC Readings and Color Coding:
    • Red: Less than 11.5 cm, indicating severe acute malnutrition (SAM).
    • Yellow: 11.5 to 12.5 cm, indicating moderate malnutrition or risk of malnutrition.
    • Green: Greater than 12.5 cm, indicating a normal nutritional status.
  • Frontline Field Workers: The tape is especially useful for frontline field workers who are often responsible for screening large numbers of children in community settings. It is simple to use, does not require advanced training, and can quickly identify children who need nutritional intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option 1 (Shelter's tape): This is incorrect; the tape is correctly called Shakir's tape.

 

Option 3 (Reading of 13.5 to 14.5 cm): This range is not considered undernourished according to the color coding system used in Shakir's tape. A reading below 11.5 cm is considered severe acute malnutrition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shakir's tape is a tool used to assess severe acute malnutrition by measuring the mid-upper arm circumference, particularly useful for frontline field workers in resource-limited settings.

questions.text: During the insertion of a Ryle’s tube, what is the best position for a conscious patient to be in? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sitting with neck flexion

 

This is the best position for a conscious patient during Ryle's tube insertion. Sitting allows for better alignment of the upper gastrointestinal tract, making it easier to guide the tube through the esophagus and into the stomach. Neck flexion helps align the crico-pharynx with the Ryle’s tube, reducing faulty tracheal insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of Ryle's tube is sitting with neck flexion.

 

Confirmation of the correct position of RT is done by:

 

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • Aspiration of gastric contents
  • X-ray chest + upper abdomen

 

The approximate length of the Ryle’s tube is 120-125 cm. There are 4 markings on the tube which indicates the traversing of the tube through various parts of the stomach

 

  1. 40 cm - Tube has traversed cardia of the stomach
  2. 50 cm - Tube has traversed body of the stomach
  3. 60 cm - Tube has traversed pylorus
  4. 70 cm - Tube has traversed duodenum

 

The length of tube to be inserted is calculated by measuring the distance between nose-tip of ear lobule-xiphoid (N-E-X rule).

questions.text: Which of the following is given as a part of the therapy for a child with severe COVID? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Corticosteroids.

 

In the management of severe COVID-19 in children, corticosteroids are the primary treatment among the given options. Corticosteroids are recommended for children with severe cases, which include conditions like acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), severe pneumonia, septic shock, and multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS).

 

Severe COVID-19 is characterized by symptoms such as SpO2 less than 90% on room air, severe chest retractions, grunting, lethargy, and signs of pneumonia with cyanosis. In these cases, corticosteroids like Dexamethasone or Methylprednisolone are used to reduce inflammation and manage the severe immune response associated with the virus.

 

Guidelines for Steroid Use in Severe COVID-19:

 

  • Indications: Corticosteroids are indicated in rapidly progressive moderate cases and all severe cases. They are generally avoided in the first 3-5 days of illness due to the risk of increased viral shedding during this period.
  • Dosage: Dexamethasone is given at a dose of 0.15 mg/kg with a maximum dose of 6 mg once a day, or Methylprednisolone at 0.75 mg/kg with a maximum dose of 30 mg once a day.
  • Duration: The treatment typically continues for 5-6 days and then is tapered off.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ivermectin: Ivermectin is not recommended for the treatment of severe COVID-19 in children. Ivermectin has been used for deworming, not for treating COVID-19.

 

Option C. Remdesivir: Remdesivir is an antiviral medication used in some hospitalized patients with mild to moderate COVID-19 but is not the primary treatment for severe cases in children. It inhibits viral replication by terminating RNA transcription prematurely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corticosteroids are recommended for the treatment of severe COVID-19 in children to manage inflammation and the severe immune response associated with the virus.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female was brought dead to the casualty. On examination there was frothing from her nose and mouth. What is the likely cause of death? (INICET NOVEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Drowning

 

The image shows frothing from nostrils which is likely to be due to drowning.

 

Postmortem changes of drowning:

 

  • Bloody froth in the airway

  • Water in the stomach and small intestine

  • Water in middle ear

  • Cerebral edema

  • Bloated and cyanosed face

  • Petrous or mastoid hemorrhage.

  • Voluminous / ballooned out lungs

  • Suffused conjunctive, dilated pupils

  • "Washerwoman" changes of the hands (shriveling of the skin) develop when submerged in water for several hours

  • Cutis anserina / goose skin- The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and a grainy appearance of the skin.

  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning.

  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.

  • Diatom test

 

Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hanging: Typically presents with a ligature mark around the neck, not frothing.

 

Option C. Strangulation: Often shows signs of external trauma to the neck, such as bruising or fractures, but not frothing.

 

Option D. Traumatic asphyxia: This results from severe chest compression, leading to petechiae and cyanosis but not usually frothing from the nose and mouth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frothing from the nose and mouth, along with other specific postmortem findings, strongly suggests drowning as the cause of death.

questions.text: Identify the egg in the picture given below: (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ancylostoma duodenale

 

The egg in the given picture is that of a hookworm. Eggs of both Ancylostoma Duodenale (old world hookworm) and Necator Americanus (new world hookworm) are identical.

 

The eggs of hookworm are:

 

  • Oval or elliptical
  • Colorless
  • Not bile stained
  • With a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane
  • Thin shell
  • Segmented ovum - 4 to 8 blastomeres
  • There is clear space between segmented ovum and egg shell
  • Eggs float in saturated salt solution.

 

Humans are infected when filariform larvae in moist soil penetrate the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ascaris lumbricoides: Ascaris lumbricoides eggs are round to oval, thick-shelled, and often bile-stained. They have a rough, mammillated outer layer.

 

Option B. Strongyloides stercoralis: Strongyloides stercoralis eggs are usually not seen in stool samples because they hatch within the intestine. The diagnostic stage is the rhabditiform larva found in the stool.

 

Option C. Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm): Enterobius vermicularis eggs are oval, flattened on one side, and have a thick, colorless shell. They are typically detected using the "Scotch tape" method.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hookworm eggs are oval, colorless, thin-shelled, and contain 4 to 8 blastomeres. These eggs are not bile-stained and have a clear space between the ovum and the eggshell.

questions.text: Identify the PTA. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mixed

 

The audiogram shows characteristics of mixed hearing loss where both conductive and sensorineural components are present:

 

  • There is an air-bone gap (separation between air and bone conduction curves) indicating a conductive component
  • The bone conduction curve is below normal (>25 dB) indicating sensorineural component
  • The air conduction shows even greater hearing loss (50-70 dB)
  • Both curves are below normal range but maintain a gap between them

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CHL (Conductive Hearing Loss): In pure conductive hearing loss, bone conduction would be normal (within 25 dB) with only air conduction being affected, creating an air-bone gap. Here bone conduction is also affected.

 

Option B. SNHL (Sensorineural Hearing Loss): In pure SNHL, both air and bone conduction curves would be affected but would be close together without significant gap. Here there is a clear air-bone gap.

 

Option D. None: The audiogram clearly shows pathological findings and cannot be considered normal where both curves would be within 25 dB with no gap.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In mixed hearing loss, the audiogram shows both bone conduction below normal (SNHL component) and an air-bone gap (conductive component), indicating pathology in both inner ear and middle/outer ear.

 

  • Whenever a PTA is given, first see whether there is air-bone gap(AC & BC curves are separated by a long gap) or not
  • If there is no air-bone gap or very little gap, then it could be sensorineural hearing loss.
  • If there is a long separation in between the AC & BC curves, then it could be either conductive or mixed.
  • First see whether the distantly separated curves are present in the upper part of the graph or lower part.
  • If occupying upper part, then it is conductive hearing loss and if occupying lower part, then it could be mixed.

choices.text: Post mortem lividity

questions.text: The postmortem change seen in the image below corresponds to which of the following?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Marbling

 

Explanation: In the above picture superficial veins are visible on the dead body which is characteristic of Marbling. Hydrogen sulphides gas produced by decomposing tissues combine with Hb to form sulph-meth-haemoglobin. This sulph-meth-haemoglobin stains the tissues and vessels producing a greenish black color called marbling.

 

 

Other options

 

Option B) Algor mortis: Algor mortis refers to the postmortem cooling of the body. After death, the body temperature gradually decreases until it reaches the ambient temperature hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option C) Rigor mortis: Rigor mortis is the stiffening of muscles that occurs after death due to ATP depletion in the muscles.

 

Option D) Post mortem lividity is a passive process of blood accumulating within the blood vessels in the dependent parts of the body as a result of gravity, causing a discoloration of the skin that varies from pink to dark purplish. The pale looking areas on the skin are the pressure areas. The below image of PM Lividity

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Marbling

 

  1. Marbling is a characteristic color change occurring in Putrefaction in which the superficial veins become visible on the skin due to staining by Hemoglobin or sulphmethhaemoglobin
  2. Mechanism of color change in putrefaction:
  1. Direct staining by Hemoglobin (Hb): Lyses of RBCs occur in putrefaction which releases the Hb. This Hb itself stains the tissues and vessels producing a reddish brown coloration which later becomes greenish black.
  2. Staining by Sulph-meth-haemoglobin: Hydrogen sulphides gas produced by decomposing tissues combine with Hb to form sulph-meth-haemoglobin. This sulph-meth-haemoglobin stains the tissues and vessels producing a greenish black color.
  1. This greenish black staining of superficial veins appears as prominent lines on the skin called Marbling
  2. Marbling is distinctly appreciable in the superficial veins of abdomen, shoulders, chest and inguinal region.
  3. Marbling starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in about 36–48 hours after death in summer

questions.text: GeneXpert detects mutations in which of the following genes? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) rроB

 

GeneXpert is a molecular diagnostic tool widely used for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and resistance to rifampicin. It identifies mutations in the rpoB gene, which encodes the beta subunit of RNA polymerase. These mutations are responsible for rifampicin resistance, a critical marker for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB).

 

rpoB: The target gene for rifampicin resistance detection by GeneXpert. Mutations here confer rifampicin resistance

 

WHO strongly recommends Xpert assay for the diagnosis of TB and multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB in patients with HIV infection (WHO 2013).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. inhA: The inhA gene is associated with resistance to isoniazid and ethionamide. However, GeneXpert does not detect mutations in this gene.

 

Option C. katG: The katG gene is associated with resistance to isoniazid, another key TB drug. GeneXpert does not detect mutations in this gene.

 

Option D. pncA: The pncA gene is associated with resistance to pyrazinamide. GeneXpert does not detect mutations in this gene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gene(s) involved in anti-tuberculosis drug resistance –

choices.text: Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.text: What causes decrease in GFR? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decrease in glomerular filtration coefficient

 

The glomerular filtration coefficient (Kf) is directly proportional to GFR according to the formula. Therefore, a decrease in Kf will lead to a decrease in GFR. The filtration coefficient represents the product of the hydraulic permeability and surface area available for filtration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure: Incorrect. A decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure will increase GFR by increasing the net filtration pressure gradient.

 

Option B. Increase in glomerular hydrostatic pressure: Incorrect. An increase in glomerular hydrostatic pressure increases GFR by promoting filtration.

 

Option D. Decrease in glomerular oncotic pressure: Incorrect. A decrease in glomerular oncotic pressure increases GFR by reducing the opposition to filtration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glomerular filtration coefficient (Kf) and GFR are directly proportional, meaning a decrease in Kf causes a decrease in GFR.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with chronic liver disease is evaluated using the Child-Pugh score, which categorizes patients into classes based on disease severity. Which type of data does the Child-Pugh scoring system represent? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ordinal

 

  • The Child-Pugh score is used to assess the severity and prognosis of chronic liver disease by categorizing patients into different classes based on specific criteria.
  • This score assigns patients to Class A, B, or C based on their total points, indicating varying levels of disease severity and prognosis.
  • It is an ordinal scale of data.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nominal: Incorrect. Nominal data involves categories without order, which does not apply to the ordered nature of the Child-Pugh score.

 

Option C. Qualitative: Incorrect. While the Child-Pugh score is qualitative in describing severity, the specific classification into ordered categories makes it ordinal.

 

Option D. Metric: Incorrect. Metric data involves quantitative measurements with consistent intervals, which does not describe the ordinal nature of the Child-Pugh score.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic presented with withdrawal symptoms. His liver function tests showed:

 

AST 140 IU/L,

 

ALT 110 IU/L, and

 

GGT 500 IU/L.

 

Which of the following benzodiazepines can be safely administered to this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lorazepam

 

The patient's liver function tests indicate elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT, and GGT), suggesting potential alcoholic hepatitis or liver impairment. In such cases, choosing the appropriate benzodiazepine is crucial due to the liver's role in drug metabolism.

 

Lorazepam is a preferred benzodiazepine in patients with liver impairment for the following reasons:

 

  1. Short-acting: Lorazepam is a short-acting benzodiazepine, which means it has a shorter half-life and less risk of accumulation in the body compared to long-acting benzodiazepines.
  2. Minimal liver metabolism: Lorazepam undergoes minimal hepatic metabolism, which makes it safer for patients with impaired liver function. This reduces the risk of adverse effects and toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diazepam: Diazepam is a long-acting benzodiazepine. It undergoes extensive hepatic metabolism, leading to active metabolites that can accumulate, especially in patients with liver dysfunction. This increases the risk of prolonged sedation and toxicity.

 

Option B. Alprazolam: Alprazolam, although shorter-acting than diazepam, still undergoes significant liver metabolism. It is not as safe as lorazepam in patients with compromised liver function.

 

Option C. Clonazepam: Clonazepam is also a long-acting benzodiazepine with extensive hepatic metabolism. Like diazepam, its use in patients with liver impairment can lead to accumulation and increased risk of side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with liver impairment, such as those with alcoholic hepatitis, lorazepam is the preferred benzodiazepine due to its short-acting nature and minimal hepatic metabolism.

questions.text: Which of the following structures does the cell pointed red arrow inhibit?(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Deep nuclei of cerebellum

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a histopathological section of the cerebellum. The cells marked with the arrow are Purkinje cells and they inhibit deep nuclei of the cerebellum.

 

Within the white matter, there are four pairs of deep cerebellar nuclei: the fastigial, globose, emboliform (these last two are collectively called the interposed nuclei), and the dentate nuclei. These nuclei receive inhibitory input from Purkinje cells and excitatory input from cerebellar afferents and provide the primary output from the cerebellum to other brain regions.

 

 

Detailed Overview of Cerebellar Architecture:

 

1. Three Layers of the Cerebellar Cortex:

 

  • Molecular Layer: This is the outermost layer and contains stellate and basket cells. The dendrites of Purkinje cells also extend into this layer. The axons of granule cells, called parallel fibers, run horizontally in this layer.
  • Purkinje Cell Layer: This layer contains the large, flask-shaped Purkinje cells, which are the principal neurons of the cerebellar cortex. Purkinje cells have a single axon that travels to the deep cerebellar nuclei and extensive dendritic trees that extend into the molecular layer. They are inhibitory neurons that use GABA as their neurotransmitter.
  • Granule Cell Layer: The innermost layer contains numerous small granule cells, along with Golgi cells. Granule cells are excitatory neurons that use glutamate as their neurotransmitter. Their axons ascend into the molecular layer where they bifurcate and run as parallel fibers, synapsing with Purkinje cell dendrites.

 

2. White Matter: Beneath the cerebellar cortex is the cerebellar white matter, which consists of myelinated axons. These axons form the afferent and efferent connections of the cerebellum.

 

3. Deep Cerebellar Nuclei: Within the white matter are four pairs of deep cerebellar nuclei: the fastigial, globose, emboliform (these last two are collectively called the interposed nuclei), and the dentate nuclei. These nuclei receive inhibitory input from Purkinje cells and excitatory input from cerebellar afferents and provide the primary output from the cerebellum to other brain regions.

 

4. Afferent and Efferent Fibers: The cerebellum receives input (afferent fibers) mainly from the spinal cord, brainstem, and cerebral cortex and sends output (efferent fibers) to the deep cerebellar nuclei and then out to various parts of the brain, primarily the vestibular nuclei and the thalamus.

 

5. Bergmann Glia: These are specialized astrocytes found in the cerebellum. They have long processes that extend through the Purkinje cell layer into the molecular layer, providing support for neurons and playing a role in neurotransmission.

 

6. Foliation: Grossly, the cerebellum exhibits a series of folia (folds) which are a result of the convolution of the cerebellar cortex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Vestibular nuclei and Option C: Basal ganglia are not directly influenced by Purkinje cells.

 

Option B: Anterior horn of spinal is involved in motor neuron activity, unrelated to Purkinje cell output.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Purkinje cells in the cerebellum play a vital inhibitory role on the deep cerebellar nuclei, crucial for coordinating and refining motor movements and cognitive processing related to movement.

choices.text: Oral hairy Leukoplakia
