questions.text: An immunocompromised patient presents with the following lesion on the lateral aspect of the tongue as shown in the image below. This white membrane was not scrapeable with a gauze piece. What is the diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral Hairy Leucoplakia

 

Option A:

 

Oral Hairy Leukoplakia:

 

  • This condition is characterized by a white, corrugated, "hairy" plaque typically found on the lateral borders of the tongue.
  • It is commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals, especially those with HIV.
  • The white membrane is not scrapeable, which helps to distinguish it from candidiasis.
  • The presence of this lesion in an immunocompromised patient that is non-scrapeable strongly indicates Oral Hairy Leukoplakia, which is associated with Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lichen Planus:

 

  • This condition usually presents as white, lace-like patterns (Wickham's striae) as shown in the image below, on the buccal mucosa, tongue, and other oral mucosa.

 

 

  • It can sometimes have erosive, painful areas, but it does not have the "hairy" appearance typical of Oral Hairy Leukoplakia.

 

Option C. Lichen Sclerosus:

 

  • This is a chronic condition that typically affects the anogenital area, not the oral mucosa.

 

 

  • It is characterized by white patches that can lead to scarring, but it does not occur on the tongue.

 

Option D. Candidiasis:

 

  • Also known as oral thrush, candidiasis presents with white patches that typically can be scraped off to reveal a red, bleeding surface underneath. The fact that the lesion in the image is not scrapeable makes candidiasis less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diagnose Oral Hairy Leukoplakia by its characteristic non-scrapeable, white, hairy appearance on the lateral aspect of the tongue, especially in immunocompromised patients.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Page no 25.33

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented with a gradually diminishing visual field. She was found to have a pituitary mass and underwent trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy. Now she has low levels of ACTH, TSH, FSH, and LH. Which of the following hormone supplements is not needed in the patient postoperatively? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mineralocorticoids

 

After a trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy, the pituitary gland's ability to produce several hormones including ACTH, TSH, FSH, and LH can be impaired. The lack of ACTH typically necessitates glucocorticoid replacement, but not mineralocorticoid supplementation. This is because the regulation of mineralocorticoids (primarily aldosterone) is mainly via the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), which operates independently of the pituitary gland. Aldosterone secretion is primarily controlled by plasma potassium levels and the RAAS, not ACTH, although ACTH can have a stimulatory effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucocorticoids: Low dose steroid supplementation is required as they are ACTH dependent.

 

Option C. Thyroid hormones: Necessary due to diminished TSH, which is essential for thyroid hormone synthesis and secretion. LT4 supplementation targeting T4 levels is required.

 

Option D. Estradiol: While gonadotropin supplementation post-pituitary surgery can be complex, replacement might be necessary due to the absence of FSH and LH, affecting estrogen levels.

 

Educational Objective:


Post-hypophysectomy, patients often require supplementation of several hormones, including glucocorticoids and thyroid hormones, due to impaired pituitary function. However, mineralocorticoid supplementation is typically not needed as aldosterone secretion is primarily regulated by the RAAS system, independent of pituitary control.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/ Chapter 379/

choices.text: Eye drops first, ointment 15 min later
Ointment first, eye drops 15 min later

questions.text: What is the correct order of using eye drops and eye ointment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Eye drops first, ointment 15 min later

 

To ensure proper absorption of medication, it is recommended to use eye drops before ointment. Eye drops have a thinner consistency and are absorbed more quickly, whereas ointments are thicker and need more time for absorption. Therefore, eye drops should be used first, followed by ointment after a gap of 15 minutes, especially when using both at the same time. Ointments are typically used at bedtime due to their prolonged absorption time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ointment first, eye drops 15 min later and D. Ointment first, then eye drops immediately: Incorrect because the ointment could prevent the eye drops from being absorbed properly by creating a barrier.

 

Note - Ointments are generally used last, particularly at bedtime, to maintain medication contact with the eye surface for an extended period, aiding in treatment effectiveness, especially in conditions requiring continuous exposure to the medication.

 

Option C. Eye drops first, then ointment immediately: Incorrect as applying ointment immediately after drops could interfere with the absorption of the drops.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Always use eye drops before eye ointment when both forms of medication are prescribed. Allowing a gap of 15 minutes between applying drops and ointment ensures maximum effectiveness of both medications without interference in absorption.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with gums bleeding, hepatosplenomegaly has a peripheral smear finding shown in the image. Flow cytometry was ordered for patient and CD19, CD22 and TdT came to be positive. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ALL B Lymphocyte Type

 

This is a case of B-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (B-ALL) based on:

 

1. Clinical presentation:

 

  • Young child (5 years old)
  • Gum bleeding (due to thrombocytopenia)
  • Hepatosplenomegaly

 

2. Peripheral smear:

 

  • Shows lymphoblasts with: 
    • Scanty agranular cytoplasm
    • Condensed chromatin
    • No abnormal granules

 

3. Flow cytometry findings:

 

  • Positive for:
    • CD19 (B-cell marker)
    • CD22 (B-cell marker)
    • TdT (terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase - immature lymphoid marker)

 

These markers are characteristic of B-cell ALL. Flow cytometry is the investigation of choice for confirming the diagnosis and lineage assignment

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ALL T Lymphocyte Type

 

  • Incorrect because T-ALL would be positive for CD1, CD2, CD5, CD7 markers
  • Usually presents with mediastinal mass
  • Flow cytometry shows different markers than presented here

 

Option C. AML

 

  • Incorrect because myeloblasts would show Auer rods and granular cytoplasm
  • Would be positive for MPO/NSE markers
  • Different flow cytometry pattern

 

Option D. CML

 

  • Incorrect because CML shows mature granulocytes with left shift
  • Presents typically in adults
  • Positive for Philadelphia chromosome
  • Different flow cytometry pattern

 

Educational Objective:

 

B-cell ALL is characterized by lymphoblasts on peripheral smear and positivity for B-cell markers (CD19, CD22) and TdT on flow cytometry.

choices.text: Plasmapheresis is not effective in refractory GBS
IV immunoglobulins are the first line of treatment
Areflexia in the weaker arm is a mandatory diagnostic criteria

questions.text: Regarding Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) in children, which of the following statements is false? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmapheresis is not effective in refractory GBS

 

Plasmapheresis (plasma exchange, PEX) is a well-established and effective treatment in GBS, including in refractory or severe cases. It is considered equivalent in efficacy to IVIG and may be used in patients not responding to IVIG (controversial, and sequential administration of PEX after IVIG is not recommended, but some clinicians try on a case-by-case basis), or if IVIG is contraindicated or unavailable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV immunoglobulins are the first line of treatment: Correct. IVIG can be used as first-line treatment, having equal efficacy to plasma exchange in GBS management.

 

Option C. Areflexia in the weaker arm is a mandatory diagnostic criteria: Correct. Areflexia in the weaker arm is a mandatory diagnostic criterion according to Brighton criteria. GBS is a demyelinating disease affecting large fibers that form the basis of reflex arcs.

 

Option D. Albumino-cytological dissociation of CSF is characterstic: Correct. It is a classic feature of GBS, with high protein in CSF but normal cell count (<10 cells). Any cell count >50 essentially rules out GBS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasmapheresis and IVIG are effective treatment options for GBS, including refractory cases, with neither being superior to the other. Never use immunosuppression or steroids in acute GBS.

 

 

Level of diagnostic certainty in Brighton criteria for GBS

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with left-sided hemiparesis. Damage to which part of the internal capsule leads to this presentation? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior limb

 

The internal capsule is a white matter structure in the brain that contains many important tracts, including those for motor and sensory functions. Damage to specific parts of the internal capsule can result in different clinical presentations based on the fibers that are affected.

 

Posterior limb is the part of the internal capsule that carries corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts, which are responsible for motor and sensory functions. Damage to the posterior limb can result in contralateral hemiparesis (weakness on the opposite side of the body). Therefore, a lesion in the posterior limb of the right internal capsule would lead to left-sided hemiparesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrolentiform: This part of the internal capsule contains optic radiations, which are involved in visual processing. Damage here would lead to visual deficits rather than motor or sensory deficits.

 

Option B. Sublentiform: This part carries auditory radiations and is involved in hearing. Damage to this part would result in auditory deficits, not motor weakness.

 

Option C. Anterior limb: This part of the internal capsule contains frontopontine fibers and thalamocortical radiations, which are involved in cognitive and executive functions. Damage here might affect cognition but not typically result in hemiparesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the posterior limb of the internal capsule can lead to contralateral hemiparesis due to the involvement of motor and sensory pathways.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not require dose reduction in patients with renal failure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Doxycycline

 

Doxycycline is an antibiotic that does not require dose adjustment in patients with renal failure because it is primarily excreted in the bile and not significantly through the kidneys. This makes it safer for use in patients with impaired renal function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gentamicin: Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that is primarily excreted by the kidneys. In patients with renal failure, the clearance of gentamicin is significantly reduced, and therefore, dose adjustments are necessary to avoid toxicity, particularly nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity.

 

Option B. Vancomycin: Vancomycin is an antibiotic that is also primarily excreted by the kidneys. In patients with renal impairment, dose adjustments are required to prevent accumulation of the drug and subsequent nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity.

 

Option C. Amphotericin B: Amphotericin B is an antifungal medication that can cause nephrotoxicity. Although its dose does not typically require adjustment based solely on renal function, careful monitoring and possible dose adjustment are often necessary to manage its renal side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The drugs which are secreted in bile and safe in renal disease include:

 

Cef in: Cefoperazone, Ceftriaxone

 

The: Tigecycline

 

R: Rifampicin

 

E: Erythromycin

 

N: Nafcillin

 

A: Ampicillin

 

L: Lincosamide (Clindamycin)

 

D: Doxycycline

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is diagnosed with a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) of the cervix and no obvious macroscopic growth. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Colposcopy and biopsy

 

In a woman diagnosed with a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL), the next step in management is to perform a colposcopy and biopsy.

 

Patients with HSIL are further evaluated using colposcopy, which involves visual inspection with acetic acid (VIA) to identify aceto-white areas and taking biopsies from any abnormal areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: Incorrect. Hysterectomy is not the immediate management for HSIL without macroscopic growth. It is considered in cases of invasive cancer or recurrent high-grade lesions when conservative management fails.

 

Option B. Conization: Incorrect. Conization may be considered if colposcopy and biopsy confirm significant dysplasia or carcinoma in situ. It is a treatment method, not the initial step.

 

Option D. Follow-up after 6 months: Incorrect. HSIL requires immediate evaluation, not delayed follow-up. Delay could increase the risk of progression to invasive cancer.

 

Educational Objective:


For HSIL, the immediate management is colposcopy and biopsy to assess the extent and severity of dysplasia. Prompt evaluation and intervention are essential to prevent the progression to invasive carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following vessels is involved in the condition affecting the region marked in red in the image shown below?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery

 

Explanation:

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome or posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) syndrome, is a neurological condition caused by a blockage or disruption of blood flow in the PICA, a major artery that supplies the medulla. It results from damage to multiple structures in the medulla, including the nuclei of cranial nerves (such as the nucleus ambiguus), the spinothalamic tract, and the descending sympathetic pathways.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior Cerebellar Artery: The superior cerebellar artery primarily supplies the superior surface of the cerebellum. Blockage or injury to this artery can lead to symptoms related to dysfunction of the upper cerebellum but is not associated with the classic features of lateral medullary syndrome.

 

Option C. Posterior Superior Cerebellar Artery: The posterior superior cerebellar artery supplies the superior part of the cerebellum and the superior cerebellar peduncle. It is not directly associated with the lateral medullary syndrome. Blockage of this artery can lead to symptoms related to the superior cerebellum but not the specific features seen in lateral medullary syndrome.

 

Option D. Cerebral Artery: The term "cerebral artery" is a broad term that refers to arteries supplying the brain, including the anterior, middle, and posterior cerebral arteries. Blockage or issues with these arteries can cause various types of strokes or neurological symptoms, but they are not directly related to lateral medullary syndrome, which specifically involves the medulla and the PICA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA) is a major artery that supplies the lateral and posterior parts of the medulla, as well as the inferior surface of the cerebellum. When there is an issue with the PICA, such as a clot or blockage, it can affect the blood supply to the lateral medulla. This leads to the classic symptoms of lateral medullary syndrome, including dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), hoarseness, vertigo, nystagmus (involuntary eye movements), ataxia (loss of coordination), and various sensory disturbances.

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, typically results from a blockage or disruption of blood flow in the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA).

questions.text: Vesicular rash is seen in __________. (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hand, foot, and mouth disease

 

Vesicular rash is seen in hand, foot, and mouth disease.

 

It is a mild exanthematous fever usually occurring in children but may also occur in adults. It is characterized by papulovesicular rashes that involve the oral mucosa, palms, and soles.

 

The virus is shed in the stool and is transmitted by the fecal-oral route. It is a self-limiting disease and subsides in 1-2 weeks. Treatment is symptomatic as the rash heals spontaneously.

 

Coxsackieviruses are enteroviruses and belong to the Picornaviridae family. They are classified into groups A and B. Group A viruses are classified into 24 types, and group B viruses are classified into 6 types.

 

Diseases caused by Coxsackie A viruses include:

 

  • Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD)
  • Herpangina – Characterized by ulcerating small vesicles on the oral fauces, or palate or uvula, and the posterior pharyngeal wall.
  • Aseptic meningitis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dengue: Cutaneous and mucosal findings in dengue are erythema, morbilliform eruptions, and hemorrhagic lesions. The rash in dengue is not typically vesicular.

 

Option C. Zika fever: Zika fever is characterized by fever, maculopapular rash, arthralgia, and conjunctivitis, but not by vesicular rashes.

 

Option D. Roseola infantum: Presents as a nonpruritic, pink papular rash that begins on the trunk, not as a vesicular rash.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key point to remember from this question is that vesicular rashes, especially involving the palms, soles, and oral mucosa, are characteristic of hand, foot, and mouth disease caused by Coxsackie A virus.

questions.text: A patient has presented for a routine eye evaluation. You have checked his visual acuity using Snellen's chart and found it to be 6/6. What is the minimum angle of resolution? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5 minutes of arc

 

The angle subtended for a patient with 6/6 vision is 5 minutes of arc.

 

Visual acuity is a measure of the spatial resolution of the eye or an estimation of its ability to discriminate between two points.

 

Snellen's chart consists of a series of letters arranged in lines, each diminishing in size. Each whole letter will subtend the angle of 5 minutes at the nodal point of the eye at the given distance.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The minimum angle of resolution for someone with a visual acuity of 6/6 using a Snellen chart is 5 minutes of arc. This indicates the precise and detailed visual capability required to resolve fine details at a standard distance, a fundamental concept in understanding and assessing visual acuity in clinical settings.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient comes to the clinic with a history of rapidly enlarging swelling in her right breast for the last 15 days. During the physical examination, there was a local rise in temperature, and the lump was partially mobile over the chest wall. What could be the probable diagnosis for this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inflammatory carcinoma

 

Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) is a rare and aggressive form of breast cancer. It presents with rapid onset of swelling (edema), redness (erythema), and warmth due to its tendency to block the lymphatic vessels in the skin of the breast. This blockage leads to the classic "peau d'orange" appearance, resembling the skin of an orange. A local rise in temperature and rapid progression of symptoms (as in 15 days) can be consistent with inflammatory carcinoma. The tumor might be mobile initially, but as the disease progresses, it becomes fixed. Given the described symptoms and rapid onset, inflammatory carcinoma is a probable diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Giant fibroadenoma: Fibroadenomas are benign tumors composed of glandular and connective tissue. They are usually painless, mobile, and have a rubbery consistency. While they don't typically present with inflammation or a rapid onset of symptoms, giant fibroadenomas are larger than typical fibroadenomas (>5cm). They are seen in the 15 to 25 year old age group.

 

Option C. Phyllodes tumor: Phyllodes tumors are rare breast tumors that can be benign, borderline, or malignant. They can grow quickly and become quite large, and while they might be mobile, they do not typically present with inflammatory signs like warmth or redness.

 

Option D. Galactocele: A galactocele is a milk-filled cyst that can form in the breast. It typically presents in women who are lactating or have recently stopped lactating. While a galactocele can cause a lump in the breast, it doesn't cause inflammatory symptoms such as a local rise in temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the given scenario, the patient's rapid onset of disease and examination findings suggest inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, which is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer.
  • Inflammatory breast cancer typically presents with brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (Peau d'orange appearance), along with a breast lump.
  • Skin biopsy is used to diagnose inflammatory breast cancer.
  • The treatment for inflammatory breast cancer includes combined-modality treatment, such as neoadjuvant chemotherapy, mastectomy, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy for ER-positive tumors, and Trastuzumab for HER-2-positive tumors.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents to the emergency department with intermittent episodes of severe colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, and passage of currant jelly stools. The clinical suspicion is towards intussusception. Taking the child's immunization history, which recent vaccine could be associated with a slightly increased risk of this condition? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Rotavirus vaccine

 

Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a complication of intussusception.

 

ROTA virus vaccines

 

  • 4 Types – but 2 used in NIS
  • ROTAVAC and ROTASIL (live, att., lyophilized with diluent citrate bicarbonate buffer)
  • ROTAVAC →1 dose = 0.5 ml
  • ROTASIIL → 1 dose – 2.5 ml with 6 ml syringe
  • 3 doses – 6, 10, 14 weeks
  • Complication - INTUSSUSCEPTION

 

 

 

Other 3 Options: Not associated with intussusception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a rare complication of intussusception, an important consideration when assessing an infant presenting with symptoms of this condition.

questions.text: Fibres of the given structure originate from? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hippocampus

 

Explanation:

 

The given structure is the fornix and its fibres arise from the hippocampus.

 

The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of white matter fibers that connects the hippocampus to other regions of the brain, including the mammillary bodies, thalamus, and septal nuclei. The fibers of the fornix arise from the hippocampus, which is involved in the formation and consolidation of memories, and then project through the fornix to other parts of the limbic system. Dysfunction of the fornix and hippocampus can result in memory impairments, as seen in conditions such as Alzheimer's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amygdala: The amygdala is a small almond-shaped structure located deep within the temporal lobes of the brain. It is involved in processing emotions, especially fear and emotional memory. While the amygdala does have connections to the limbic system, it is not a direct source of fibers for the fornix. However, it does interact with the hippocampus and other limbic structures.

 

Option B. Mammillary Body: The mammillary bodies are a pair of small, round structures located on the undersurface of the brain, specifically in the diencephalon. They are closely connected to the hippocampus and are considered part of the limbic system. The fornix sends fibers to and receives fibers from the mammillary bodies, facilitating the flow of information within the limbic circuit.

 

Option C. Caudate Nucleus: The caudate nucleus is a component of the basal ganglia and is involved in motor control and cognitive functions. While it interacts with some limbic structures, it is not a primary source of fornix fibers. Instead, it has connections with other regions involved in motor control and reward processing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hippocampus is a critical structure within the limbic system that plays a central role in memory formation and spatial navigation. It is the primary source of fibers that make up the fornix. The fornix carries information from the hippocampus to other limbic structures, including the mammillary bodies and the anterior thalamic nuclei, as well as to the septal nuclei and the cingulate gyrus.

questions.text: During your residency, you learn about a specific protocol essential for physicians when dealing with challenging scenarios. This protocol, known as the SPIKES protocol, serves a unique purpose in medical communication. Can you identify the primary objective of employing the SPIKES protocol? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Breaking bad news

 

SPIKES PROTOCOL

 

  • Communication of cancer Diagnosis & Prognosis (or any adverse outcome)
  • Protocol of 6 steps

S - Set up interview

P - Perceptions

I - Invitation to explain

K - Knowledge

E - Emotions

S - Summary & Strategy

 

Best used for Communication of diagnosis and prognosis for Breast Cancer

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triage: Incorrect. Triage involves prioritizing patient care based on the severity of their condition.

 

Option B. Consent for study participation: Incorrect. Obtaining consent for study participation requires a different communication protocol focused on informed consent.

 

Option C. Hospital infection control: Incorrect. Infection control involves protocols for preventing and managing infections within the hospital setting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The SPIKES protocol is specifically designed to guide physicians in breaking bad news to patients, ensuring the communication is handled with sensitivity and clarity.

questions.text: The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is a critical parameter used to evaluate maternal health within countries. In the context of public health statistics, how is the Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) for a country conventionally expressed? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Maternal deaths per 100,000 live births

 

  • MMR is Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births.
  • Maternal Mortality ratio (MMR): Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births, where a ‘maternal death’ is defined as ‘death of a woman while pregnant or during delivery or within 42 days (6 weeks) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of duration or site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes’.

 

MMR is a ratio 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is expressed as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, providing a measure of the safety and quality of maternal care in a country.

choices.text: Should not be used due to risk of addiction
Can be used as both have different mechanism of action
Should not be used as it is irrational
Can be used to treat cough effectively

questions.text: If Codeine is coming to the market in combination with dextromethorphan as an anti-tussive, this combination? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Should not be used as it is irrational

 

  • Codeine is an opioid agonist and Dextromethorphan is a centrally acting NMDA receptor antagonist. Both codeine and dextromethorphan are antitussives, but they work through similar central mechanisms to suppress cough. Combining them does not offer additional therapeutic benefits but can increase the risk of side effects
  • A rational fixed dose drug combination would be to combine one centrally acting anti-tussive (either codeine or dextromethorphan) with expectorants (like potassium iodide, Guaifenesin), antihistaminic and mucolytics like (Ambroxol, Bromhexine, Acetyl cysteine)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Should not be used due to risk of addiction: While codeine has a potential for addiction, the main concern with this combination is not solely the risk of addiction but the lack of rationality in combining two centrally acting antitussives.

 

Option B. Can be used as both have different mechanisms of action: This is incorrect. Codeine and dextromethorphan both act centrally to suppress cough, and their mechanisms are similar enough that combining them does not provide a significant therapeutic advantage.

 

Option D. Can be used to treat cough effectively: Although both drugs are effective cough suppressants individually, their combination is not advisable due to the redundancy in action and increased risk of side effects without additional therapeutic benefit.

 

Therefore, the most accurate answer is C. The combination should not be used as it is irrational due to the overlapping mechanisms of action and increased risk of adverse effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Combining codeine with dextromethorphan as an anti-tussive is irrational due to their overlapping mechanisms of action and the increased risk of side effects without additional therapeutic benefit. Rational combinations for cough treatment involve combining one centrally acting antitussive with expectorants, antihistamines, and mucolytics.

questions.text: Match the following teratogenic drugs with their teratogenic effects: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

The correctly matched pairs of teratogenic drugs and their effects is 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a.

 

  1. Lithium is used in the treatment of bipolar disorders and prophylaxis of mania. It is c/I in pregnancy as it leads to Ebstein’s anomaly in the fetus, which is characterised by arterialization of the right ventricle and a box shaped heart.
  2. Warfarin leads to defect in the growth of the cartilage (chondrodysplasia punctata) characterized by depressed nasal bridge, stippled epiphyses etc. Warfarin embryopathy is maximally seen when it is used between 6-9 weeks.
  3. Thalidomide causes proximal limb defect or Phocomelia. Thalidomide acts via inhibiting angio-genesis, inhibiting cereblon and suppressing immune responses.
  4. Chloramphenicol inhibits peptidyl transferase. It causes Bone Marrow suppression and leads to grey baby syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The teratogenic effects of certain drugs is crucial for managing medication use during pregnancy. Lithium can cause Ebstein’s anomaly, Warfarin is associated with saddle nose and growth retardation, Thalidomide causes limb malformations, and Chloramphenicol can lead to Grey Baby Syndrome.

questions.text:
An unconscious child is brought to the casualty. What is the correct sequence of the management? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Assess breathing
  2. Assess pulse
  3. Assess response
  4. Start compressions
  5. Bag and mask ventilation
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3-1-2-4-5

 

When managing an unconscious child, especially in a potential cardiac or respiratory arrest scenario, it is crucial to follow the steps of Basic Life Support (BLS) in the correct sequence to ensure the best chance of recovery.

 

 

Sequence Justification:

 

  • The correct sequence is 3-1-2-4-5, which means:
    • 3: First, assess response (to determine unresponsiveness).
    • 1: Then assess breathing (to check for normal breathing).
    • 2: Followed by assessing the pulse (to check for circulation).
    • 4: Start compressions if necessary (if no pulse or poor perfusion).
    • 5: Provide bag and mask ventilation to support breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In BLS, the correct sequence of actions is crucial for effective management. Start by assessing response, followed by breathing and pulse, then initiate compressions and ventilation as needed.

choices.text: Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side
Vertical nystagmus towards the same side
Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side
Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side

questions.text: During the process of conducting a caloric test, what kind of nystagmus should one anticipate when using cold water irrigation?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side

 

In caloric testing, cold water irrigation produces horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side.

 

Fitzgerald-Hallpike test or bithermal caloric test procedure:

 

  • Patient is made to lie supine with the head tilted 30° forward so that the horizontal canal is vertical.

 

 

  • Irrigation stimulates the lateral/ horizontal semicircular canal which produces horizontal nystagmus.
  • Cold water induces nystagmus to the opposite side and warm water to the same side (remember mnemonic COWS: cold-opposite, warm-same)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side: This option is incorrect for cold water irrigation. Cold water causes the fluid in the horizontal semicircular canal to move in a way that induces nystagmus towards the opposite side, not the same side.

 

Option B. Vertical nystagmus towards the same side and Option D. Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side: Vertical nystagmus does not occur in caloric testing, as this test specifically stimulates the horizontal semicircular canal, inducing horizontal nystagmus. Vertical nystagmus is generally associated with different pathologies and is not a result of standard caloric testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The caloric test, particularly when using cold water, is designed to stimulate the horizontal semicircular canal, resulting in horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side. This test is critical for evaluating unilateral weaknesses in the vestibular system and helps in diagnosing conditions affecting balance and spatial orientation.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, page No. 45

choices.text: Both the statement and the reason are true, and the reason explains the statement correctly.
Both the statement and the reason are true, but the reason does not explain the statement.
The statement is false, but the reason is true.
Both the statement and the reason are false.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the given statements: 

 

Assertion: WHO recommends Typhoid Vaccine for disaster management in endemic areas.


Reason: Vaccination is a cost-effective method of disaster control.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both the statement and the reason are false.

 

The WHO does not recommend vaccines such as typhoid, cholera, or tetanus for the general population after a disaster. These vaccinations are, however, advised for healthcare workers who are at a higher risk due to their roles in managing post-disaster health scenarios.

 

In the context of post-disaster management, the most effective approach to preventing disease spread includes the provision of safe drinking water and the proper disposal of excreta, rather than vaccination for the general population. These measures address the root causes of potential outbreaks and are more practical and effective under post-disaster conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

WHO does not recommend widespread typhoid vaccination after a disaster. Instead, providing safe water and sanitation is essential for preventing disease in affected areas.

questions.text: Which of the following colored cannula will you use to achieve maximum flow rate, in a patient who needs a large amount of fluids?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Grey


The grey-colored cannula (16G) is specifically used to achieve a high flow rate of 236 ml/min, which is ideal for situations where a patient requires a significant volume of fluids, such as in major surgeries, trauma, gastrointestinal bleeds, and multiple blood transfusions. This large bore size allows for rapid infusion, making it suitable for high-volume fluid resuscitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Green (18G): This cannula has a flow rate of 103 ml/min, which is slower than the grey cannula and is primarily used for blood products, contrast studies, and delivery of certain medications.

 

Option C. Blue (22G): The blue cannula has a significantly lower flow rate of 42 ml/min, making it suitable only for fragile veins and cytotoxic therapy, not for large-volume fluid replacement.

 

Option D. Pink (20G): The pink cannula has a flow rate of 67 ml/min and is used for general IV maintenance, IV antibiotics, and IV analgesics, rather than high-volume fluid resuscitation.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A blood spill in the operation theatre must be cleaned with? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chlorine compound

 

Sodium hypochlorite, a compound of chlorine, is the best disinfectant for surface blood spills. It is used with a concentration of 0.5-5%.

 

If the spill contains large amounts of blood or body fluids, clean the visible matter with disposable absorbent material and discard the contaminated materials in appropriate, labelled containment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phenolic compound: Phenolic compounds are effective disinfectants but are generally less effective against a broad spectrum of bloodborne pathogens compared to chlorine compounds.

 

Option C. Quaternary ammonium compounds: Quaternary ammonium compounds are good for general disinfection but are not recommended for blood spills as they are less effective against non-enveloped viruses and spores.

 

Option D. Alcoholic compounds: Alcohol-based disinfectants are effective for surface disinfection but are not ideal for blood spills as they can coagulate proteins, making blood more difficult to clean.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For cleaning a blood spill in the operation theatre, sodium hypochlorite, a chlorine compound, is the best disinfectant due to its effectiveness in inactivating a wide range of pathogens and its suitability for such critical environments.

questions.text: Which among the following is a subcutaneous fungal agent? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sporothrix schenckii

 

Sporothrix schenckii is a subcutaneous fungal agent. It is the causative agent of sporotrichosis, commonly known as "rose gardener's disease." This fungal infection occurs when the fungus, which lives in soil, plants, and decaying vegetation, enters the skin through small cuts or punctures. The infection usually starts as a small nodule at the site of entry and can spread along lymphatic channels, causing nodular lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptococcus neoformans: This fungus is typically associated with systemic infections, particularly cryptococcal meningitis, in immunocompromised individuals, especially those with HIV/AIDS. It is not classified as a subcutaneous fungal agent.

 

Option B. Histoplasma capsulatum: This is a systemic mycotic agent that causes histoplasmosis, a respiratory infection that can disseminate in immunocompromised individuals. It is not a subcutaneous fungal agent.

 

Option D. Talaromyces marneffei: Formerly known as Penicillium marneffei, this fungus causes systemic mycoses, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those with HIV/AIDS. It is endemic in Southeast Asia and not classified as a subcutaneous fungal agent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

The term systemic mycoses is used here to refer to infections caused by organisms in the following genera: Blastomyces, Coccidioides, Paracoccidioides, Histoplasma, and Cryptococcus.

questions.text: DNA-Protein interactions can be studied by using: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DNA footprinting

 

  • DNA footprinting is a technique used to study DNA-protein interactions. It involves the selective cleavage or modification of DNA sequences by a DNA-binding protein. By analyzing the resulting pattern of cleavage or modification, researchers can determine which regions of the DNA are bound by the protein, effectively "footprinting" its interaction sites.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA fingerprinting: DNA fingerprinting is a technique used to identify individuals based on their unique DNA patterns, primarily in the context of forensic science and paternity testing. It is not specifically used to study DNA-protein interactions.

 

Option C. Northern Blotting: Northern blotting is a molecular biology technique used to study gene expression by analyzing the presence and quantity of specific RNA molecules in a sample. It is not primarily used to study DNA-protein interactions but rather RNA-related processes.

 

Option D. ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay): ELISA is an immunological assay used to detect the presence of specific antibodies or antigens in a sample. While it can indirectly provide information about protein-protein interactions, it is not a direct method for studying DNA-protein interactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA footprinting is the appropriate method for studying DNA-Protein interactions, as it allows researchers to identify the specific binding sites of proteins on DNA by selectively cleaving or modifying the DNA sequence. This technique is fundamental for understanding how proteins interact with DNA in various biological processes.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 451

choices.text: Differential mRNA processing

questions.text: Affinity maturation of antibodies is because of? ((INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Somatic hypermutation

 

Option A. Somatic hypermutation: Affinity maturation primarily occurs in the germinal centers of secondary lymphoid organs, such as lymph nodes and spleen. The cause of affinity maturation is Somatic hypermutation.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Differential mRNA Processing: This process involves chemical modification of mRNA during mRNA processing. While it is important for generating diversity in certain proteins, it is not directly related to affinity maturation of antibodies.

 

Option C. CD40: CD40 is a co-stimulatory molecule involved in B cell activation. It plays a role in the interaction between B cells and T cells. While it is important for various aspects of immune response, it is not the primary cause of affinity maturation.

 

Option D. Gene Rearrangements: Gene rearrangements, specifically V(D)J recombination, occur during the early development of B cells. This process creates diversity in the variable regions of antibody genes. While important for generating initial antibody diversity, it is not the primary cause of affinity maturation.

 

Educational objective:

 

Affinity maturation is a process by which antibodies undergo modifications to enhance their binding affinity for a specific antigen over time. This is crucial for the adaptive immune system to generate more effective and specific immune responses.

 

Somatic Hypermutation (SHM):

Definition: Somatic hypermutation is a process that introduces point mutations into the variable regions of immunoglobulin genes in B cells.

 

Location: It occurs in the germinal centers of secondary lymphoid organs during the B cell response to an antigen.

 

Purpose: The primary goal of somatic hypermutation is to introduce random mutations in the variable regions of the immunoglobulin genes, leading to a diverse set of antibodies with different binding affinities.

 

Outcome: B cells that produce antibodies with higher affinity for the antigen are selectively favored and survive, while those with lower affinity may undergo apoptosis.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus which lasts minutes to hours with accompanied nausea and vomiting. On investigation, there is endolymphatic hypertension present. What is the diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meniere’s disease

The patient's symptoms and the diagnostic finding of endolymphatic hypertension align with Meniere's disease. 

Characterized by episodes of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness, lasting from minutes to hours. The symptoms are due to the accumulation of fluid in the inner ear (endolymphatic hydrops), leading to increased pressure within the endolymphatic system.

Other Options:

 Option B. Otosclerosis: A condition primarily affecting the bones of the middle ear, particularly the stapes. It causes conductive hearing loss, not typically associated with vertigo or tinnitus of the type seen in Meniere’s disease.

Option C. Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV): Characterized by brief episodes of vertigo related to changes in head position. It involves the dislodgment of otoliths within the inner ear, leading to brief, intense episodes of vertigo, without the auditory symptoms typical of Meniere's disease. 

Option D. Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma): A benign tumor on the vestibular nerve, leading to progressive, unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance disturbances. It usually does not cause episodic vertigo like Meniere's disease.

Educational Objective:

Meniere’s disease is a chronic condition that requires management of symptoms through lifestyle changes, medications to control vertigo, and sometimes more invasive treatments to manage fluid pressure in the inner ear.

questions.text: Desmosomes are abundant in which of the following layer of skin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A

 

Desmosomes are abundant in the stratum spinosum layer of the epidermis of the skin. Stratum spinosum in the above image is represented by 'A'.

 

The desmosomes appear like spines on microscopy and hence this layer is also called as the prickle layer.

 

Keratinocytes in the skin's epidermis are connected by desmosomes, also known as macula adherens. It is a cell structure designed specifically for adhesion between cells.

 

  • Due to their strong adhesiveness, they can withstand mechanical stress.
  • Desmoglein (Dsg), Desmocollin (DsC), and DesmoPlakin (Dp) are some of the proteins found in desmosomes.
  • Acantholysis can result from the separation of keratinocytes caused by the loss of any one protein.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune condition brought on by antibodies that target Desmoglein found in desmosomes.
  • Loss of desmosomes causes keratinocyte cohesion to break down (acantholysis), which leads to blister formation.
  • Diseases of the skin and the heart can result from desmosome dysfunction. The primary cause of arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy is mutations within the desmosomes (ARVC).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stratum Corneum (B): This layer is the outermost layer of the epidermis, consisting of dead, keratinized cells. Its main function is to provide a barrier to protect underlying tissue.

 

Option C. Stratum Basale (D): This is the deepest layer of the epidermis, responsible for generating new cells. Desmosomes are present here but not as abundant as in the stratum spinosum.

 

Option D. Stratum Granulosum (C): This layer is characterized by granules of keratohyalin, which play a role in the keratinization process of the skin cells. While desmosomes may be found in this layer, they are more prominent in the stratum spinosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stratum spinosum, indicated by arrow A, is the layer of the skin where desmosomes are most abundant. These structures are key for cell adhesion and strength in this layer, which is situated above the stratum basale and below the stratum granulosum.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page no 2.1, 2.2, 2.18

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented with a history of bilateral lower limb weakness which progressed to his upper limbs in a year. On examination, he had weakness in both lower limbs and wasting in the left upper limb. Babinski sign was positive and the deep tendon reflexes were absent. He has no sensory loss or any autonomic dysfunction. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ALS


Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by mixed upper and lower motor neuron signs. The presence of both Babinski sign (an upper motor neuron sign) and absent deep tendon reflexes (a lower motor neuron sign), along with the chronic progression and lack of sensory/autonomic involvement, strongly points towards ALS.

 

Other Options:


Option A. MS: Multiple sclerosis typically involves sensory symptoms and demyelinating plaques visible on MRI, which are not described here.

 

Option C. GBS: Guillain-Barré Syndrome is an acute condition with a rapid onset and is primarily a lower motor neuron disease without upper motor neuron signs like the Babinski reflex.

 

Option D. Tropical spastic paraparesis: This condition is associated with HTLV-1 infection and presents predominantly with upper motor neuron signs, not the mixed signs seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ALS presents with both upper and lower motor neuron signs, progressive weakness, and no sensory or autonomic dysfunction.

questions.text: A patient suffered from tibial fracture following a road traffic accident. He complained of pain on passive flexion. His posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses were palpable, but he had loss of sensation in the 1st webspace. What will be the next step? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Measure anterior compartment pressure

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndrome, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.
  • Most commonly compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).
  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.
  • Most common cause is fractures and dislocations.
  • Other causes of compartment syndrome are:
    • Crush injury/Burn/Infection/Surgical procedure/Tight circumferential dressing
    • Exercise: Exercise may increase intracompartmental pressure and muscle edema, so it is avoided in cases of acute compartmental syndrome.
       
  • Clinical Features:
    • The diagnosis is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.
    • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) – 1st sign
    • Order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intracompartmental pressure is: capillary compression, venous compression, arterial compression.
    • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome.
    • The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
    • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.
    • Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated compared with pressures in other compartments. Deep flexor muscles are involved particularly flexor digitorum profundus > flexor pollicis longus.
    • Acute compartment syndrome presents with the following 5 Ps:

 

 

  • Treatment: 
    • The limb should be kept at the level of heart rather than elevated.
    • Removal of all circumferential dressing reduce pressure up to 85%.
    • Fasciotomy is recommended in the presence of clinical signs of compartment syndrome, such as undue pain and a palpable firmness in the forearm. The morbidity caused by fasciotomy is minimal, whereas that caused by an untreated compartment syndrome is much greater.
       
  • The general indications for fasciotomy are:
    • Impending tissue ischemia
    • When the tissue pressure reaches 30 mm Hg or the difference between diastolic blood pressure and compartment pressure is less than 30 mm Hg (Normal compartment pressure is 8-10 mm Hg and pressure at calf during walking is 200-300 mm Hg).
       
  • A higher pressure is a strong indication that fasciotomy should be recommended.
  • In a hypotensive patient, the acceptable pressure is lower.

 

Extra Edge:

 

 

Other option:

 

Option A. Reapply cast. Application of cast will further put pressure on the leg compartments. So, this treatment method will not help.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In this clinical scenario, the pain on passive flexion is the first sign of compartment syndrome. Pulselessness is the late feature. So it is advised to measure the compartment pressure first.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inferior gluteal artery

 

  • Origin: The inferior gluteal artery is typically a branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Course & Supply: It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, usually below the piriformis muscle. It supplies the gluteal muscles (mainly gluteus maximus), and also gives off branches that participate in anastomoses around the hip joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iliolumbar Artery

 

  • Origin: This arises from the posterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Course & Supply: It ascends posteriorly to supply the iliacus muscle, the iliac bone, and the lumbosacral region. Its branches also participate in anastomoses with the lumbar arteries.

 

Option B. Lateral Sacral Artery

 

  • Origin: This too arises from the posterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Course & Supply: Generally, there are two lateral sacral arteries (superior and inferior) that descend to supply the sacrum and coccyx. They anastomose with the median sacral artery and with each other. Some branches of the lateral sacral arteries also supply the meninges of the sacral part of the spinal cord.

 

Option D. Superior Gluteal Artery

 

  • Origin: This artery arises from the posterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Course & Supply: It leaves the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, usually above the piriformis muscle. It supplies the gluteal muscles and also contributes to the anastomotic network around the hip joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Branches of the anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

 

  1. Vaginal artery (in females)
  2. Uterine artery (in females)
  3. Inferior vesical artery (in males) or vaginal artery (in females): supplies the urinary bladder and reproductive organs.
  4. Middle rectal artery: supplies the rectum and anal canal.
  5. Internal pudendal artery: supplies the perineum, external genitalia, and the lower anal canal.
  6. Obturator artery: supplies the adductor muscles of the thigh, external genitalia, and the hip joint.
  7. Inferior gluteal artery: supplies the muscles of the gluteal region.
  8. Superior vesical artery: supplies the urinary bladder and the vas deferens.

questions.text: Which of the following triad is seen after an acute attack of angle-closure glaucoma? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vogt's triad

 

  • Vogt's triad is seen after an acute attack of primary angle-closure glaucoma.
  • It includes glaukomflecken, patches of iris atrophy, and a slightly dilated nonreactive pupil.
  • Glaukomflecken is used to describe an anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity due to necrosis of lens cortical fibers.
  • The mid-dilated pupil is attributed to sphincter atrophy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Virchow triad is used to describe the abnormalities that result in thrombosis. It includes endothelial injury, abnormal blood flow, and hypercoagulability of the blood.

 

Option C. Hutchinson triad is used to describe manifestations of congenital syphilis. It includes interstitial keratitis, Hutchinson teeth, and eighth nerve deafness. Hutchinson teeth are screw-driver or peg shaped small incisors.

 

Option D. Gaucher's triad is not a named triad. Hypertonia, strabismus, and stridor usually point to a diagnosis of type 2 Gaucher's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vogt's triad in a patient with a history of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma can aid in rapid diagnosis and management of this potentially vision-threatening condition. It underscores the importance of timely intervention to preserve ocular health and prevent irreversible complications.

questions.text: INSURE technique is used in newborn, born with which condition?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyaline membrane disease

 

The INSURE technique stands for INtubate, SURfactant, and Extubate. This method is used primarily in the management of preterm infants with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), also known as hyaline membrane disease. The procedure involves:

 

  1. Intubating the newborn to establish a secure airway.
  2. Administering surfactant directly into the lungs to reduce surface tension and improve lung function.
  3. Extubating the newborn after the surfactant has been given to allow for spontaneous breathing with the aid of non-invasive ventilation, if necessary.

 

Hyaline membrane disease occurs in preterm infants due to the immaturity of the lungs and a deficiency of surfactant, a substance that prevents the alveoli in the lungs from collapsing. The INSURE technique is effective in providing the necessary surfactant and reducing the severity of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meconium aspiration syndrome: This option is incorrect because meconium aspiration syndrome occurs in post-term infants who inhale meconium-stained amniotic fluid, leading to respiratory distress. The INSURE technique is not used for this condition.

 

Option B. Transiente tachypnea of newborn: This option is incorrect because transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN) is a self-limited condition seen in term infants caused by delayed clearance of fetal lung fluid. It typically resolves without the need for surfactant administration.

 

Option D. Neonatal jaundice: This option is incorrect because neonatal jaundice, caused by elevated bilirubin levels, is not related to lung function or surfactant deficiency. The INSURE technique is not applicable to this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The INSURE technique (Intubate, Surfactant, Extubate) is primarily used in preterm infants with hyaline membrane disease to administer surfactant and improve lung function.

choices.text: Transfusion related circulatory overload

questions.text: A CKD patient had to undergo dialysis and his Hb was 5.2gm/dL. So two blood transfusions were to be given. The first bag was completed in 2 hours. The second was started and in the midway, he developed shortness of breath and hypertension. Vitals Were BP - 180/120 mmHg and pulse rate - 110 min. What is the cause? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transfusion related circulatory overload

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO).

 

Transfusion associated circulatory overload includes any four of the following occurring within 6 h of a blood transfusion - acute respiratory distress, tachycardia, increased blood pressure (BP), acute or worsening pulmonary edema and evidence of a positive fluid balance.

 

TACO may occur due to rapid or excess transfusion of red cell preparations or plasma products.

 

Prevented is by slow transfusion at the rate of 1 to 2 ml of blood/kg of body weight per hour. Diuretics are also used if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic: Allergic reactions to blood transfusions usually present with urticaria (hives), pruritus (itching), and sometimes anaphylaxis, but do not typically cause the significant hypertension and tachycardia seen in this case.

 

Option C. Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI): TRALI is characterized by acute onset of non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, leading to respiratory distress and hypoxemia during or within 6 hours of transfusion. However, TRALI typically presents with hypotension or normal blood pressure, not the significant hypertension seen here.

 

Option D. Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction: This reaction typically presents with fever, chills, and rigors, but does not cause the hemodynamic instability (hypertension and tachycardia) seen in TACO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transfusion-related circulatory overload (TACO) is a potential complication of blood transfusion, particularly in patients with predisposing conditions like CKD. It presents with respiratory distress, hypertension, and tachycardia and can be prevented by careful monitoring and slow transfusion.
